[[File:3DISCO imaging of mouse brain.jpg|thumb]] '''3DISCO''' (stands for “3D imaging of solvent-cleared organs“)<ref name=":05">{{Cite journal|last=Ertürk|first=Ali|last2=Becker|first2=Klaus|last3=Jährling|first3=Nina|last4=Mauch|first4=Christoph P|last5=Hojer|first5=Caroline D|last6=Egen|first6=Jackson G|last7=Hellal|first7=Farida|last8=Bradke|first8=Frank|last9=Sheng|first9=Morgan|date=November 2012|title=Three-dimensional imaging of solvent-cleared organs using 3DISCO|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nprot.2012.119|journal=Nature Protocols|language=En|volume=7|issue=11|pages=1983–1995|doi=10.1038/nprot.2012.119|issn=1750-2799}}</ref> is [[Histology|histological]] method which make biological samples more transparent (so called “cleared”), by using series of organic solvents for matching [[refractive index]] (RI) of tissue and surrounding medium. Structures in transparent tissues can be examined by [[Fluorescence microscope|fluorescence microscopy]] without need for time-consuming physical sectioning and following reconstruction ''in silico''.
The method was developed by team around [[Ali Ertürk]] and Hans-Ulrich Dodt from Max-Planck-Institute in Munich<ref name=":05" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Ertürk|first=Ali|last2=Mauch|first2=Christoph P.|last3=Hellal|first3=Farida|last4=Förstner|first4=Friedrich|last5=Keck|first5=Tara|last6=Becker|first6=Klaus|last7=Jährling|first7=Nina|last8=Steffens|first8=Heinz|last9=Richter|first9=Melanie|date=2011-12-25|title=Three-dimensional imaging of the unsectioned adult spinal cord to assess axon regeneration and glial responses after injury|journal=Nature Medicine|volume=18|issue=1|pages=166–171|doi=10.1038/nm.2600|issn=1546-170X|pmid=22198277}}</ref> primarily for clearing and imaging unsectioned mouse brain and spinal cord. Later on the method or its modifications were successfully used in many fields of biological research to image and investigate whole body of mouse,<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Pan|first=Chenchen|last2=Cai|first2=Ruiyao|last3=Quacquarelli|first3=Francesca Paola|last4=Ghasemigharagoz|first4=Alireza|last5=Lourbopoulos|first5=Athanasios|last6=Matryba|first6=Paweł|last7=Plesnila|first7=Nikolaus|last8=Dichgans|first8=Martin|last9=Hellal|first9=Farida|date=October 2016|title=Shrinkage-mediated imaging of entire organs and organisms using uDISCO|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nmeth.3964|journal=Nature Methods|language=En|volume=13|issue=10|pages=859–867|doi=10.1038/nmeth.3964|issn=1548-7105}}</ref> structure and function of mouse brain,<ref name=":05" /> stem cells,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Espinosa-Medina|first=I.|last2=Outin|first2=E.|last3=Picard|first3=C. A.|last4=Chettouh|first4=Z.|last5=Dymecki|first5=S.|last6=Consalez|first6=G. G.|last7=Coppola|first7=E.|last8=Brunet|first8=J.-F.|date=2014-07-04|title=Neurodevelopment. Development|journal=Cell|volume=169|issue=1|pages=161–173.e12|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2017.03.008|issn=1097-4172|pmid=28340341}}</ref>
== History and development of method == Use of organic solvents for clearing (making transparent) the tissue was first mentioned more than century ago by German anatomist [[Werner Spalteholz]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/11138774|title=Über das Durchsichtigmachen von menschlichen und tierischen Präparaten und seine theoretischen Bedingungen, nebst Anhang: Über Knochenfärbung.|last=Spalteholz|first=Werner|date=1914|publisher=S. Hirzel|location=Leipzig|language=German}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Steinke|first=H.|last2=Wolff|first2=W.|title=A modified Spalteholz technique with preservation of the histology|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0940960201800200|journal=Annals of Anatomy - Anatomischer Anzeiger|volume=183|issue=1|pages=91–95|doi=10.1016/s0940-9602(01)80020-0}}</ref> But with some exceptions <ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eitel|first=F.|last2=Seibold|first2=R.|last3=Hohn|first3=B.|last4=Schweiberer|first4=L.|date=July 1986|title=[Preparatory technical modification and standardization of the Spalteholz microangiographic study method]|journal=Der Unfallchirurg|volume=89|issue=7|pages=326–336|issn=0177-5537|pmid=3529403}}</ref> (reviewed in <ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Azaripour|first=Adriano|last2=Lagerweij|first2=Tonny|last3=Scharfbillig|first3=Christina|last4=Jadczak|first4=Anna Elisabeth|last5=Willershausen|first5=Brita|last6=Noorden|first6=Cornelis J.F. Van|title=A survey of clearing techniques for 3D imaging of tissues with special reference to connective tissue|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0079633616300043|journal=Progress in Histochemistry and Cytochemistry|volume=51|issue=2|pages=9–23|doi=10.1016/j.proghi.2016.04.001}}</ref>) was clearing techniques for whole 20th century almost forgotten. Their renaissance came in last decade, probably thank to spread of advanced techniques of fluorescence microscopy which allow [[optical sectioning]] of the specimen ([[Confocal microscopy|confocal]], [[Two-photon excitation microscopy|multiphoton]] or [[Light sheet fluorescence microscopy|light sheet microscopy]]).<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Silvestri|first=Ludovico|last2=Costantini|first2=Irene|last3=Sacconi|first3=Leonardo|last4=Pavone|first4=Francesco Saverio|date=March 2016|title=Clearing of fixed tissue: a review from a microscopist’s perspective|url=https://www.spiedigitallibrary.org/journals/Journal-of-Biomedical-Optics/volume-21/issue-8/081205/Clearing-of-fixed-tissue--a-review-from-a-microscopists/10.1117/1.JBO.21.8.081205.short|journal=Journal of Biomedical Optics|volume=21|issue=8|pages=081205|doi=10.1117/1.jbo.21.8.081205|issn=1083-3668}}</ref>
Of actual [[clearing techniques]], first used organic solvent was mixture of [[benzyl alcohol]] and [[benzyl benzoate]] (BABB). Authors used this solution to clear mouse brain, mouse embryos and whole body of ''D. melanogaster''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dodt|first=Hans-Ulrich|last2=Leischner|first2=Ulrich|last3=Schierloh|first3=Anja|last4=Jährling|first4=Nina|last5=Mauch|first5=Christoph Peter|last6=Deininger|first6=Katrin|last7=Deussing|first7=Jan Michael|last8=Eder|first8=Matthias|last9=Zieglgänsberger|first9=Walter|date=April 2007|title=Ultramicroscopy: three-dimensional visualization of neuronal networks in the whole mouse brain|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nmeth1036|journal=Nature Methods|language=En|volume=4|issue=4|pages=331–336|doi=10.1038/nmeth1036|issn=1548-7105}}</ref> Main drawback of this solution is bleaching of [[GFP protein|GFP]] signal and insufficient clearing of highly myelinated tissue of adult animals.<ref name=":05" /> Therefore, many other reagents were tested with aim to find GFP compatible and more sufficient clearing. As results [[tetrahydrofuran]] (THF) and dibenzyl ether (DBE) were chosen as the best regents for clearing.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Becker|first=Klaus|last2=Jährling|first2=Nina|last3=Saghafi|first3=Saiedeh|last4=Weiler|first4=Reto|last5=Dodt|first5=Hans-Ulrich|date=2012-03-30|title=Chemical Clearing and Dehydration of GFP Expressing Mouse Brains|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0033916|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=7|issue=3|pages=e33916|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0033916|issn=1932-6203}}</ref> Based on those findings the 3DISCO protocol was published in 2012.<ref name=":05" />
== Procedure == 3DISCO protocol consists of three steps:
# initial dehydration performed with tetrahydrofuran (THF) # following extraction of lipids via incubation in dichlormethane (DCM) # immersion in dibenzyl ether (DBE) for RI matching
=== Principle and protocol === The biological samples (tissues) are heterogeneous structures consist of compounds which differ in their refractive indexes. For example, water have RI 1.33, lipids and proteins around 1.40 – 1.45.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Genina|first=Elina A.|last2=Bashkatov|first2=Alexey N.|last3=Tuchin|first3=Valery V.|date=November 2010|title=Tissue optical immersion clearing|journal=Expert Review of Medical Devices|volume=7|issue=6|pages=825–842|doi=10.1586/erd.10.50|issn=1745-2422|pmid=21050092}}</ref> As result the light is scattered on its path through the tissue, which leads to decrease in resolution or even to disappearance of signal in samples thicker than few tents of micrometers. Series of steps including dehydration and delipidation of tissue and its subsequent incubation and imaging in medium with RI similar to imaged structures therefore decrease the scattering of light and leads to transparent sample.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Richardson|first=Douglas S.|last2=Lichtman|first2=Jeff W.|title=Clarifying Tissue Clearing|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0092867415008375|journal=Cell|volume=162|issue=2|pages=246–257|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2015.06.067|pmc=4537058}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Ertürk|first=Ali|last2=Bradke|first2=Frank|title=High-resolution imaging of entire organs by 3-dimensional imaging of solvent cleared organs (3DISCO)|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0014488612004013|journal=Experimental Neurology|volume=242|pages=57–64|doi=10.1016/j.expneurol.2012.10.018}}</ref>
After fixation with (usually with [[paraformaldehyde]]) and eventually labeling with dyes, the samples are dehydrated via incubation in solutions with growing concentration (50%, 70%, 80% and 100% in water) of tetrahydrofurane (THF). Because its lack of reactive alcohol, aldehyde or ketone groups, THF is less reactive and preserve fluorescence better than other dehydrating solutions.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":3" /> After dehydration the sample is rinsed first in [[Dichloromethane|dichlormethane]] (DCM) and finally in dibenzyl ether (DBE) to match the refractive index of tissue and surrounding medium leading to transparent sample. In DBE samples are stored and imaged as well.<ref name=":05" />
=== Labeling === 3DISCO protocol is best suited for fixed tissues labeled with strong fluorophores, ideally transgenic models expressing fluorescent proteins such as GFP (alternatively staining with synthetic dyes is possible as well).<ref name=":4" /> For antibody labeling the 3DISCO method was optimized and published under name iDISCO (see below Modifications and applications).<ref name="Renier 896–910" />
=== Benefits and drawbacks === Whole process is relatively easy to perform and require just changes of given solutions with no need for some customized laboratory equipment. Process of clearing and subsequent imaging is fast (hours to days depending on sample size), especially in comparison with physical sectioning of whole organ, imaging of their parts and reconstruction before subsequent image analysis (that could easily take several weeks).<ref name=":05" /><ref name=":4" /> Above that 3DISCO works on many types of tissues (lung, spleen, lymph nodes, mammary gland, tumors).<ref name=":05" /><ref name="Renier 896–910" />
Main drawbacks of this method are partial delipidation of tissue during clearing discriminating use of lipophilic dyes, shrinkage of tissue during clearing,<ref name=":4" /> partial degradation of fluorescence,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hama|first=Hiroshi|last2=Hioki|first2=Hiroyuki|last3=Namiki|first3=Kana|last4=Hoshida|first4=Tetsushi|last5=Kurokawa|first5=Hiroshi|last6=Ishidate|first6=Fumiyoshi|last7=Kaneko|first7=Takeshi|last8=Akagi|first8=Takumi|last9=Saito|first9=Takashi|date=October 2015|title=ScaleS: an optical clearing palette for biological imaging|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nn.4107|journal=Nature Neuroscience|language=En|volume=18|issue=10|pages=1518–1529|doi=10.1038/nn.4107|issn=1546-1726}}</ref> complete degradation of fluorescence during long term storage<ref name=":05" /> and toxicity of used reagents (and their potential to damage the microscopy objectives if leak from imaging chamber).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lloyd-Lewis|first=Bethan|last2=Davis|first2=Felicity M.|last3=Harris|first3=Olivia B.|last4=Hitchcock|first4=Jessica R.|last5=Lourenco|first5=Filipe C.|last6=Pasche|first6=Mathias|last7=Watson|first7=Christine J.|date=2016-12-13|title=Imaging the mammary gland and mammary tumours in 3D: optical tissue clearing and immunofluorescence methods|url=https://doi.org/10.1186/s13058-016-0754-9|journal=Breast Cancer Research|volume=18|pages=127|doi=10.1186/s13058-016-0754-9|issn=1465-542X}}</ref>
== Modifications and applications == Note that this chapter illustrates development and use of solvent-based clearing methods and does not provide complete list of applications and modifications of them.
=== Modifications === 3DISCO method was soon after publication adopted by other researchers and modified with aim to specific goals, like use of retrograde<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Launay|first=Pierre-Serge|last2=Godefroy|first2=David|last3=Khabou|first3=Hanen|last4=Rostene|first4=William|last5=Sahel|first5=Jose-Alain|last6=Baudouin|first6=Christophe|last7=Parsadaniantz|first7=Stéphane Melik|last8=Goazigo|first8=Annabelle Reaux-Le|title=Combined 3DISCO clearing method, retrograde tracer and ultramicroscopy to map corneal neurons in a whole adult mouse trigeminal ganglion|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0014483515001967|journal=Experimental Eye Research|volume=139|pages=136–143|doi=10.1016/j.exer.2015.06.008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Žygelytė|first=Emilija|last2=Bernard|first2=Megan E.|last3=Tomlinson|first3=Joy E.|last4=Martin|first4=Matthew J.|last5=Terhorst|first5=Allegra|last6=Bradford|first6=Harriet E.|last7=Lundquist|first7=Sarah A.|last8=Sledziona|first8=Michael|last9=Cheetham|first9=Jonathan|title=RetroDISCO: Clearing technique to improve quantification of retrograde labeled motor neurons of intact mouse spinal cords|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0165027016301194|journal=Journal of Neuroscience Methods|volume=271|pages=34–42|doi=10.1016/j.jneumeth.2016.05.017}}</ref> or antibody labeling (iDISCO),<ref name="Renier 896–910" /> clearing whole body of mouse (uDISCO)<ref name=":6" /> or clearing of formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded samples (DIPCO).<ref name=":8" />
Authors of iDISCO (stands for “immunolabeling-enabled imaging of solvent-cleared organs“) included pretreatment of sample with methanol, hydrogen peroxide, [[detergent]]s and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) together with [[Immunolabeling|antibody labeling]] before clearing. This preprocess overcome two drawbacks of antibody labeling of large samples. First lowering the autofluorescence of samples and enhance signal-to-noise ratio, and second make tissue more penetrable for antibodies. As result samples as large as mouse embryos or whole mouse organs can be successfully dyed with fluorescent labeled antibodies and thereafter cleared and imaged.<ref name="Renier 896–910" />
Authors of uDISCO (from “ultimate imaging of solvent-cleared organs“) enhance a shrinkage of tissue, a common bystander effect of dehydration of sample in first step of clearing. They used [[Tert-Butyl alcohol|tert-butanol]] instead of THF for dehydration and also different solution for imaging, which preserve fluorescence better than DBE. Thank to shrinkage of the tissue, they can observe large samples up to size of whole mouse body.<ref name=":6" /> It is worth to mention that uDISCO was highlighted by media worldwide including New York Times,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/23/science/transparent-mouse-udisco-glow.html|title=Seeing Through to a Mouse’s Nervous System|last=Fleur|first=Nicholas St|date=2016-08-22|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-14|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Wall Street Journal,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/new-technique-shrinks-makes-whole-animals-transparent-1471878084|title=New Technique Shrinks, Makes Small Animals Transparent|last=Hernandez|first=Daniela|date=2016-08-22|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-04-14|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> Business Insider,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.de/transparent-mouse-udisco-2016-8/?r=US&IR=T|title=A 'revolutionary' new technology can turn mice clear — and might one day map your brain|work=Business Insider Deutschland|access-date=2018-04-14|language=de}}</ref> Nature and Science<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/08/scientists-can-see-through-these-rodents|title=Scientists can see through these rodents|date=2016-08-22|work=Science {{!}} AAAS|access-date=2018-04-14|language=en}}</ref> magazines. It was also chosen as one of the top 10 scientific images of 2016 by Nature.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cressey|first=Daniel|date=2016-12-22|title=2016 in pictures: The best science images of the year|url=https://www.nature.com/news/2016-in-pictures-the-best-science-images-of-the-year-1.21156|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=540|issue=7634|pages=500–505|doi=10.1038/540500a}}</ref>
DIPCO (from “diagnosing immunolabelled paraffin-embedded cleared organs”) is pipeline combine deparaffinization of FFPE embedded tumor specimens, iDISCO clearing and phenotyping of tumor tissue. Tumor FFPE samples are widely stored in biobanks and used for diagnostics, and their 3D analysis could potentially help to improve stratification of cancer patients.<ref name=":8" />
=== Applications === Clearing methods, including 3DISCO, was mainly developed for [[neuroscience]] research first. The reason is in high morphological and functional complexity of [[nervous system]], which investigation is time-consuming and laborious with classical histology methods.<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Belle|first=Morgane|last2=Godefroy|first2=David|last3=Dominici|first3=Chloé|last4=Heitz-Marchaland|first4=Céline|last5=Zelina|first5=Pavol|last6=Hellal|first6=Farida|last7=Bradke|first7=Frank|last8=Chédotal|first8=Alain|title=A Simple Method for 3D Analysis of Immunolabeled Axonal Tracts in a Transparent Nervous System|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S2211124714009061|journal=Cell Reports|volume=9|issue=4|pages=1191–1201|doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2014.10.037}}</ref> Majority of studies is therefore focused on mouse [[central nervous system]] (rodents are one of main [[model organism]]s for neurobiology). Authors of 3DISCO method used it first for studying regeneration in the central nervous system (CNS) of mouse, including counting of [[microglia]], [[astrocyte]]s and mapping trajectories of [[axon]]s after injury.<ref name=":0" /> 3DISCO was also used for mapping the development of mouse CNS.<ref name=":0" /> Its modification iDISCO was used for functional studies of brain activity<ref name="Renier 896–910" /> or for mapping [[amyloid]] plaques, microglia, vasculature and other properties of brains in [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer diseased]] patients and mouse models.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liebmann|first=Thomas|last2=Renier|first2=Nicolas|last3=Bettayeb|first3=Karima|last4=Greengard|first4=Paul|last5=Tessier-Lavigne|first5=Marc|last6=Flajolet|first6=Marc|title=Three-Dimensional Study of Alzheimer’s Disease Hallmarks Using the iDISCO Clearing Method|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S2211124716308142|journal=Cell Reports|volume=16|issue=4|pages=1138–1152|doi=10.1016/j.celrep.2016.06.060}}</ref> Modification uDISCO was then used for single cell mapping of neurons in whole unsectioned CNS of mouse.
In recent years the use of “DISCO” methods is broadened to research on many other tissues, including single-cell mapping of transplanted [[stem cell]]s in whole mouse organs,<ref name=":6" /> imaging of whole human embryos in different developmental stages<ref name=":5" /> or examination and diagnostics of human tumors tissue.<ref name=":8" />

{{nofootnotes|date=August 2010}} '''Agustín Feced''' (born June 11, 1921, died 1980s or 1990s) was a Major and Commander of the [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[Gendarmería Nacional Argentina|National Gendarmerie]], and the head of the Police of the [[Santa Fe Province|Province of Santa Fe]] for the city of [[Rosario]], during the [[Dirty War]]. He was in charge of the 2nd Regional Police Corps, and he was also part of [[Batallón de Inteligencia 601|Intelligence Battalion 601]] of the [[Argentine Army]] since June 1974, before the beginning of the military dictatorship, in the last days of the presidency of [[Juan Perón]].
He was born in [[Acebal, Santa Fe]]. He was officially declared dead in 1986 but this is disputed, it has been widely claimed that he was still alive after this date.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elciudadanoweb.com/el-testimonio-de-la-sobrina-del-mas-cruel-torturador/|title=El testimonio de la sobrina del más cruel torturador|work=Diario El Ciudadano y la Región|access-date=2018-06-15|language=es-ES}}</ref>
==Disappearance== Between 1976 and 1979, and already under the dictatorship of the [[Proceso de Reorganización Nacional]], Feced was the head of the Intelligence Service of the 2nd Corps, which doubled as an illegal detention center (the major one in the area, of a total of about 10). His office coordinated the repressive scheme in Rosario and its neighboring areas. People were kidnapped by squads and taken to the IS to be held and tortured. Feced is known to have taken part in the kidnappings, in torture sessions when the victim was for some reason interesting to him, and in the killings, which were often conducted in faraway locations and sometimes passed as fights between the police and armed terrorists. Two of Feced's foremost assistants in these crimes were [[José Rubén Lo Fiego]] and [[Mario Alfredo Marcote]].
The Intelligence Service is now a memorial site called ''[[Centro Popular de la Memoria]]'' (People's Memorial Center), preserved by an organization of victims' relatives.
==Initial investigations== According to the extensive research conducted after the end of the Proceso, 720 people were "disappeared" in Santa Fe and 350 in Rosario. Feced, together with then-Commander of the 2nd Army Corps [[Leopoldo Galtieri]], is considered responsible for most of them. Before the closing of the case against him, Feced was accused of 270 crimes against humanity. Though Rosario had comparatively a smaller amount of "disappeared" people than other metropolitan areas, the proportion of those kidnapped that were set free from the detention centers and camps is also smaller, and there were many more victims of torture and murder.
The Supreme Council of the Armed Council started an investigation about Feced in 1983, and produced a large amount of documentation including lists of missing people, anonymous burials in a cemetery in Rosario, and tens of criminal collaborators.
==Feced's cover-up and alleged death== This investigation took 3 years before it was passed on to the Federal Justice in Rosario. Feced was in theory to be in prison since the official opening of the case on January 31, 1984; later he was transferred by justice to the custody of the Military Hospital of Campo de Mayo (Buenos Aires). There he is claimed to have undergone heart surgery in 1985. At the time, though, he was in fact free in [[Formosa, Argentina|Formosa]]. These facts point to complicity and protection by many powerful interest (military, government officials, and some powerful businessmen such as [[Alberto Gollán]]). On July 21, 1986, Feced was officially declared dead by the Military Hospital.
Many witnesses, survivors of the IS, claim to have seen Feced alive after that date. An admission book of the Ariston Hotel in Rosario, presented as evidence to the court by journalist Claudio de Luca, showed a signature with Feced's handwriting, dated July 29, 1988. Francisco Oyarzábal, brother of a murdered victim, reported that Feced had been seen alive in [[Paraguay]].
The investigation of the Intelligence Service case was archived in 1987 after the passing of the laws called ''[[Ley de Obediencia Debida]]'' (Law of Due Obedience) and ''[[Ley de Punto Final]]'' (Full Stop Law), during the presidency of [[Raúl Alfonsín]], which restricted the accountability for human rights abuses to the highest levels of the military hierarchy (who had been already tried) and put an end to ongoing criminal investigations into the lower levels.
On December 15, 1989, the Penal Federal Court of Rosario, without giving weight to the above inconsistencies, declared the case against Feced extinct (closed) due to his alleged death. The rest of the people involved in the crimes of the Intelligence Service were [[pardon]]ed by decree of President [[Carlos Menem]] in 1989–1990.
==Del Frade's research== Research conducted by journalist Carlos del Frade since 1999, and published in 2002, shows that Feced's last recorded [[domicile (law)|domicile]] was in the city of [[Buenos Aires]]. Though he was supposedly ill and senile, one of his former neighbors, interviewed by del Frade, contradicts this impression.
Within the San Antonio Cemetery in Formosa, in the area reserved for members of the Gendarmería, there is a grave with the name of Agustín Feced, and an announcement in the local newspaper ''La Mañana'' says that he was buried there the same day of his death, at 5:30 PM. The official records of the cemetery show only one person being buried there and then, and it is not Feced; but he does appear in an old notebook also found there. The unofficial record in the notebook was written by Ramón Giménez, Feced's son-in-law and then a top government official. Feced's coffin is sealed in the wall next to another one that dates from the mid-1990s, and almost 3 meters above the ground. According to the guardian of the cemetery, San Antonio did not have lifts for coffins "until a few years ago" (1999), and work hours are 8:00 AM to 1:00 PM, so Feced could not have been buried like that "unless [somebody] brought three ladders and a lot of people to get [the coffin] up there."
==Re-opening of the case== The case against the officers of the Intelligence Division, including Feced and many of his collaborators, was re-opened by federal judge Omar Digerónimo on September 6, 2004, who ordered a number of arrests. José Lo Fiego, Mario Marcote and another former police officer, José Carlos Scortechini, surrendered themselves almost immediately, but denying all the accusations.

[[Elisabeth of Brandenburg (1207-1231)|Elisabeth]] | birth_date = {{circa| 1177}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date|1220|2|25|df=yes}} | death_place = }} '''Albert II, Margrave of Brandenburg''' (born: {{circa| 1177}} – died: 25 February 1220) was a member of the [[House of Ascania]]. He was [[Margrave]] of [[Margraviate of Brandenburg|Brandenburg]] from 1205 until his death in 1220. == Life == Albert II was the youngest son of [[Otto I, Margrave of Brandenburg|Otto I]] and his second wife [[Ada of Holland]].{{sfn|Lyon|2013|p=241}} His father Otto I promoted and directed the foundation of German settlement in the area, which had been predominantly Slavic until the 12th century. === Count of Arneburg === Albert II was, from 1184 onwards, [[Count]] of [[Arneburg]] in the [[Altmark]]. The Altmark belonged to [[Margraviate of Brandenburg|Brandenburg]], and his older brother [[Otto II, Margrave of Brandenburg|Otto II]] claimed that this implied that the Ascanians owned Arneburg. Albert participated in the [[Third Crusade]] (1189–1192). After his return, he was temporarily imprisoned in 1194 by Otto for unexplained reasons. He was present at the inaugural meeting of the [[Teutonic Knights]] in 1198 in [[Acre (city)|Acre]]. === Margrave of Brandenburg === Albert II inherited the Margraviate in 1205, after the death of his eldest brother [[Otto II, Margrave of Brandenburg|Otto II]]. In the dispute about the imperial crown between the Houses of [[Hohenstaufen]] and [[House of Guelph|Guelph]] in the early 13th century, Albert initially supported the Hohenstaufen King [[Philip of Swabia]], like Otto before him. After Philip's assassination in 1208, however, he changed sides, because Emperor [[Otto IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Otto IV]] had assisted him in securing the Margraviate against the Danes, and had confirmed Ascanian ownership of Brandenburg in a deed in 1212. During this period, Albert II had a lengthy dispute with Archbishop [[Albert I of Käfernburg|Albert I]] of [[Diocese of Magdeburg|Magdeburg]]. He also played an important rôle in the [[Brandenburg tithe dispute]]. Albert II definitively secured the [[Teltow (region)|regions of Teltow]], [[Prignitz]] and parts of the [[Uckermark]] for the Margraviate of Brandenburg, but lost [[Pomerania]] to the [[House of Griffins]]. === Death and succession === Albert II died in 1220. At the time, his two sons were still minors. Initially, archbishop Albert I of Magdeburg acted as regent. In 1221, however, Albert's widow, Countess Matilda, took up the regency. After her death in 1225, the brothers were declared legal adults and began ruling the Margraviate jointly. == Legacy == Stephan Warnatsch describes Otto I's children as follows:{{sfn|Warnatsch|2000|p=26}} ''[They] continued the territorialisation drive that had been initiated [by their father] and, from the end of the 12th Century, as the [[Ostsiedlung|influx of settlers]] grew stronger, and, consequently, more people were available to develop the territory, started to expand into the areas of Ruppin, and in particular, Barnim and Teltow. Moreover, the [[Oder]] region and the southern Uckermark were also targets of the Ascanian expansion. In all these areas, the Ascanians ran into opposition from competing local princes.'' == Marriage and issue == In 1205, Albert married Matilda of Groitzsch (1185–1225), daughter of the Count [[Conrad II, Margrave of Lusatia|Conrad II of Lusatia]],{{sfn|Lyon|2013|p=241}} a member of the [[House of Wettin]], and wife Elizabeth, from the Polish [[Piast dynasty]]. They had four children: * [[John I, Margrave of Brandenburg|John I]] (born: {{circa|1213}}; died: 4 April 1266) * [[Otto III, Margrave of Brandenburg|Otto III "the Pious"]] (born: 1215; died: 9 October 1267) * [[Matilda of Brandenburg, Duchess of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Matilda]] (died: 10 June 1261), married in 1228 Duke [[Otto I, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg|Otto I "the Child"]] of Brunswick-Lüneburg (1204–1252), a member of the [[House of Guelph]] * [[Elisabeth of Brandenburg (1206-1231)|Elizabeth]] (born: 1207; died: 19 November 1231),Accurate data can be found in: Anton Ziegler (ed.), ''Historische Memorabilien des In- und Auslandes'', vol. 1, Lechner's Universitätsbuchhandlung, Vienna, 1846, chapter 82, right-hand column married in 1228 Landgrave [[Henry Raspe]] of [[Thuringia]] (1201–1247) == Ancestors == {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1= 1. {{Refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{For|the orchid genus|Ambrella (plant)}} {{Infobox company | name = Ambrella
株式会社アムブレラ | logo = Ambrella.PNG | type = Private | foundation = 1996 | location = [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] | key_people = Norio Matsumura, Muneaki Ozawa | industry = [[Computer and video game industry]] | products = [[Pokémon (video game series)|''Pokémon'' games]] for [[Nintendo]] [[video game console]]s | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = }} '''Ambrella''' ({{nihongo|Kabushiki-Gaisha Amuburera | 株式会社アムブレラ |lead=yes}}) is a [[Japan]]ese [[video game developer|video game development company]] that works under a publishing agreement with [[Nintendo]] best known for making spin-off games for the [[Pokémon (video game series)|''Pokémon'' video game franchise]]. Ambrella was formerly a part of [[Marigul Management]]. == Overview == Ambrella developed the [[Nintendo 64]] voice recognition game, ''[[Hey You, Pikachu!]]'' in 1998, ''[[Pokémon Channel]]'' for the [[Nintendo GameCube]] in 2003, and ''[[Pokémon Dash]]'' for the [[Nintendo DS]] in 2004. Ambrella developed ''[[My Pokémon Ranch]]'' for the [[Wii]]'s [[WiiWare]] service, which was released in Japan on March 25, 2008, and in North America on June 9, 2008. It developed ''[[Pokémon Rumble]]'' which was released in North America on November 16, 2009.{{cite web|url=http://plusd.itmedia.co.jp/games/articles/0710/11/news008_2.html|title=体験会で遊んでみました――「Wii Ware」編 (2/2)|publisher=IT Media | language=Japanese | accessdate=July 2, 2016}} The company has developed further entries in the ''Pokémon Rumble'' series with ''[[Pokémon Rumble Blast]]'' for [[Nintendo 3DS]], ''[[Pokémon Rumble U]]'' for the [[Wii U]], and ''[[Pokémon Rumble World]]'' for the Nintendo 3DS. The most recent ''Rumble'' games were released via the [[Nintendo eShop]], and contain some variant of microtransactions; ''Pokémon Rumble World'' uses traditional microtransactions and ''Pokémon Rumble U'' uses [[Near field communication|NFC]] figurines that predate [[Amiibo]]. == Gameography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Platforms !! {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Assassination of Ataullah Shah | partof = [[Targeted killings in Pakistan]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = {{Location map|Dera Ismail Khan#Khyber Pakhtunkhwa#Pakistan|lat_deg=31.835094|lon_deg=70.912976|label=Bannu Ada}} | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = Bannu Ada, [[Dera Ismail Khan]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]] | target = Ataullah Shah | coordinates = {{coords|31|50|6.34|N|70|54|46.71|E|display=inline, title}} | date = 19 August 2017 | time = Morning | timezone = [[Pakistan Standard Time|PST]] | type = [[Shooting]] | fatalities = 1 (Shah) | weapons = Guns | numparts = | motive = [[Sectarianism in Pakistan|Sectarian violence]] | charges = }} {{Terrorist attacks in Pakistan}}
On 19 August 2017, Attaullah Shah, a prominent worker of [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (F)]], was shot dead by unknown assailants at Bannu ada, [[Dera Ismail Khan]], [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]], [[Pakistan]]. No one claimed responsibility of the assault.
== Biography == Ataullah Shah originated from Paniyala and was leaving in [[Dera Ismail Khan]] for several years. He was a [[Spirituality|spiritual teacher]] and was serving as [[Khatib|Khateeb]] (sermon-giver) of a local mosque. Shah was considered a member of [[Jamiat Ulema-e-Islam (F)]] and was aide of its chief [[Maulana Fazl-ur-Rehman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.geo.tv/latest/154335-jui-fs-local-leader-shot-dead-in-di-khan|title=JUI-F local leader shot dead in Dera Ismail Khan|work=[[Geo News]]|first=Marwat|last=Saeedullah|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/224716-JUI-F-leader-shot-dead-in-DI-Khan|title=JUI-F leader shot dead in DI Khan|work=[[The News International]]|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
== Background ==
=== JUI (F)'s members' execution === In May 2017, [[2017 Mastung suicide bombing|a suicide bombing]] targeting [[Abdul Ghafoor Haideri]], a leader of JUI (F), left 25 people dead. However Haideri himself managed to escape.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shahid|first1=Saleem|title=28 die as Senate deputy leader survives bomb attack in Mastung|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1332799|accessdate=8 October 2017|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|date=13 May 2017}}</ref> The current attack came weeks after Qari Haq Nawaz, leader of JUI (F), was shot dead by unknown assailants in [[Charsada]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1466983/jui-f-leader-qari-haq-nawaz-gunned-charsadda/|title=JUI-F leader Qari Haq Nawaz gunned down in Charsadda|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|date=26 July 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
=== Recent killings in the city === [[Dera Ismail Khan]] has been home to terrorism in the past. There had been many incidents of bombings. However, for the past half a decade, there had been no such incident in the city. The violence sparked again in August 2017. Two police constables were gunned down on August 11 near Kotli Imam Hussain Imambargah. Two days later, a government servant was shot dead at his doorstep in Maryali area. A milk-seller was critically injured due to firing in Eidgah on August 17.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1352559|title=JUI-F leader shot dead in Dera Ismail Khan|work=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|first=Akbar|last=Ali|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
== Shooting == Shah was walking to home after offering [[Fajr prayer]]. In the way, gunmen riding on a motorcycle opened fire, and killed him. The gunmen managed to flee.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/pakistan/jui-f-leader-attaur-rehman-shah-shot-dead-in-dera-ismail-khan/|title=JUI-F leader Ataullah Shah shot dead in Dera Ismail Khan|work=[[Pakistan Today]]|first=Ali|last=Sarfaraz|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> Local police chief Amjad Khan says, "Attaullah Shah was walking towards home after praying at a mosque in the city of Dera Ismail Khan, when the assailants opened fire early Saturday morning."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nation.com.pk/national/19-Aug-2017/unidentified-gunmen-kill-close-aid-of-fazlur-rehman|title=Unidentified gunmen kill close aid of Fazlur Rehman|work=[[The Nation (Pakistan)]]|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> As the news of his death spread, several workers of JUI (F) gathered at the hospital.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abbtakk.tv/en/jui-f-leader-gunned-down-in-di-khan/|title=JUI-F Leader Gunned Down in D.I Khan|work=[[Abb Takk News]]|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> No one claimed responsibility of attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/pakistan/hardline-islamic-party-leader-shot-dead-in-northwest-pakistan-4803574/|title=Hardline Islamic party leader shot dead in northwest Pakistan|work=[[The Indian Express]]|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> Security forces cordoned off the area and started a search operation. Shops and business centers remained closed as the fear spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1485696/jui-f-leader-gunned-dera-ismail-khan/|title=Pre-dawn ambush: Religious scholar killed in DI Khan attack|work=[[The Express Tribune]]|first=Seemab|last=Ramzan|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> His funeral prayer was offered on the evening of the day he was killed. Shah's body was sent to his native town, Paniyala for burial.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/08/19/jui-f-local-leader-killed-in-firing-incident-in-dera-ismail-khan/|title=JUI-F local leader killed in firing incident in Dera Ismail Khan|work=[[Pakistan Today]]|date=19 August 2017|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>

In [[neurology]], the '''Bereitschaftspotential''' or '''BP''' (from [[German language|German]], "''readiness potential''"), also called the '''pre-motor potential''' or '''readiness potential''' ('''RP'''), is a measure of activity in the [[motor cortex]] and [[supplementary motor area]] of the brain leading up to voluntary muscle movement. The BP is a manifestation of cortical contribution to the pre-[[motor planning]] of volitional movement. It was first recorded and reported in 1964 by [[Hans Helmut Kornhuber]] and [[Lüder Deecke]] at the [[Albert Ludwigs University of Freiburg|University of Freiburg]] in [[Germany]]. In 1965 the full publication appeared after many control experiments.<ref name="K&D65">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF00412364|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/34700192_Hirnpotentialnderungen_bei_Willkrbewegungen_und_passiven_Bewegungen_des_Menschen__Bereitschaftspotential_u._reafferente_Potentiale._Ausz._(Mit_7_Textabb.)/file/79e415061c9c7f2b93.pdf|title=Hirnpotentialänderungen bei Willkürbewegungen und passiven Bewegungen des Menschen: Bereitschaftspotential und reafferente Potentiale|journal=Pflügers Archiv für die Gesamte Physiologie des Menschen und der Tiere|volume=284|pages=1–17|year=1965|last1=Kornhuber|first1=Hans H.|last2=Deecke|first2=Lüder}}; Englisch translation: {{cite journal | vauthors = Kornhuber HH, Deecke L | title = Brain potential changes in voluntary and passive movements in humans: readiness potential and reafferent potentials | journal = Pflügers Archiv: European Journal of Physiology | volume = 468 | issue = 7 | pages = 1115–24 | year = 2016 | pmid = 27392465 | doi = 10.1007/s00424-016-1852-3 | url = }}, [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Lueder_Deecke/publication/305040327_Brain_potential_changes_in_voluntary_and_passive_movements_in_humans_readiness_potential_and_reafferent_potentials/links/578f652208ae9754b7eced8d.pdf PDF] (accessed October 21, 2016).</ref>
== Discovery == In the spring of 1964 [[Hans Helmut Kornhuber]] (then docent and chief physician at the department of neurology, head Professor Richard Jung, university hospital Freiburg im Breisgau) and [[Lüder Deecke]] (his doctoral student) went for lunch to the 'Gasthaus zum Schwanen' at the foot of the Schlossberg hill in Freiburg. Sitting alone in the beautiful garden they discussed their frustration with the passive brain research prevailing worldwide and their desire to investigate self-initiated action of the brain and the will. Consequently, they decided to look for cerebral potentials in man related to volitional acts and to take voluntary movement as their research paradigm.<ref name="K&D90">Kornhuber, H.H.; Deecke, L. (1990). Readiness for movement – The Bereitschaftspotential-Story, ''Current Contents Life Sciences'' '''33''': 14. (Citation Classic) [http://www.garfield.library.upenn.edu/classics1990/A1990CH18100001.pdf PDF]</ref>
The possibility to do research on electrical brain potentials preceding voluntary movements came with the advent of the 'computer of average transients' (CAT computer), invented by [[Manfred Clynes]], the first still simple instrument available at that time in the Freiburg laboratory. In the [[electroencephalogram]] (EEG) little is to be seen preceding actions, except of an inconstant diminution of the α- (or μ-) rhythm. The young researchers stored the electroencephalogram and [[electromyogram]] of self-initiated movements (fast finger flexions) on tape and analyzed the cerebral potentials preceding movements time-reversed with the start of the movement as the trigger, literally turning the tape over for analysis since they had no reversal playback or programmable computer. A potential preceding human voluntary movement was discovered and published in the same year.<ref name="K&D64">{{cite journal | last1 = Kornhuber | first1 = H.H. | last2 = Deecke | first2 = L. | year = 1964 | title = Hirnpotentialänderungen beim Menschen vor und nach Willkürbewegungen, dargestellt mit Magnetbandspeicherung und Rückwärtsanalyse | url = | journal = Pflügers Arch Eur J Physiologie | volume = 281 | issue = | page = 52 }}</ref> After detailed investigation and control experiments such as passive finger movements the [[Citation Classic]] with the term ''Bereitschaftspotential'' was published.<ref name="K&D90" />
== Mechanism == [[File:Bereitschaftspotenzial fig1.jpg|frame|right|Typical recording of a Bereitschaftspotential]] The BP is ten to hundred times smaller than the [[alpha wave|α-rhythm]] of the EEG; only by averaging, relating the electrical potentials to the onset of the movement it becomes apparent. Figure shows the typical slow shifts of the cortical DC potential, called Bereitschaftspotential, preceding volitional, rapid [[flexion]]s of the right index finger. The vertical line indicates the instant of triggering t = 0 (first activity in the EMG of the agonist muscle). Recording positions are left precentral (L prec, C3), right precentral (R prec, C4), mid-parietal (Pz); these are unipolar recordings with linked ears as reference. The difference between the BP in C3 and in C4 is displayed in the lowest graph (L/R prec). Superimposed are the results of eight experiments as obtained in the same subject (B.L.) on different days. see Deecke, L.; Grözinger, B.; Kornhuber H.H. (1976)
Note that the BP has two components, the early one (BP1) lasting from about −1.2 to −0.5; the late component (BP2) from −0.5 to shortly before 0 sec.<ref name="Deeckeetal76">{{cite journal | last1 = Deecke | first1 = L. | last2 = Grözinger | first2 = B. | last3 = Kornhuber | first3 = H.H. | year = 1976 | title = Voluntary finger movement in man: Cerebral potentials and theory | url = | journal = Biol Cybern | volume = 23 | issue = | pages = 99–119 | doi=10.1007/bf00336013}}</ref> The pre-motion positivity is even smaller, and the motor-potential which starts about fifty to sixty milliseconds before the onset of movement and has its maximum over the contralateral precentral hand area is still smaller. Thus, it takes great care to see these potentials: exact triggering by the real onset of movement is important, which is especially difficult preceding speech movements. Furthermore, artifacts due to head-, eye-, lid-, mouth-movements and respiration have to be eliminated before averaging because such artifacts may be of a magnitude which makes it difficult to render them negligible even after hundreds of sweeps.<ref name="Grözingeretal80">Grözinger, B.; Kornhuber, H.H.; Kriebel, J.; Szirtes, J.; Westphal, K.T.P. (1980). The Bereitschaftspotential preceding the act of speaking. Also an analysis of artifacts. pp 798–804 in Kornhuber H.H., Deecke L., eds., Motivation, motor and sensory processes of the brain: Electrical potentials, behaviour and clinical use. ''[[Progr Brain Res]]'' '''54''', Amsterdam, Elsevier.</ref> In the case of eye movements eye muscle potentials have to be distinguished from cerebral potentials. In some cases animal experiments were necessary to clarify the origin of potentials such as the R-wave. Therefore, it took many years until some of the other laboratories were able to confirm the details of Kornhuber & Deecke's results. In addition to the finger or eye movements as mentioned above, the BP has been recorded accompanying willful movements of the wrist, arm, shoulder, hip, knee, foot and toes. It was also recorded prior to speaking, writing and also swallowing.<ref name="Huckabeeetal03">Huckabee, M.L.; Deecke, L.; Cannito, M.P.; Gould, H.J.; Mayr, W. Cortical control mechanisms in volitional swallowing: the Bereitschaftspotential. ''Brain Topogr''. '''16''': 3–17 (2003).</ref>
The magnetoencephalographic (MEG) equivalent of the Bereitschaftspotential (BP), 'Bereitschafts(magnetic)field' (BF), or readiness field (RF) was first recorded in Hal Weinberg's laboratory at Simon Fraser University Burnaby B.C. Canada in 1982.<ref name="Deeckeetal82">{{cite journal | last1 = Deecke | first1 = L | last2 = Weinberg | first2 = H. | last3 = Brickett | first3 = P. | year = 1982 | title = Magnetic fields of the human brain accompanying voluntary movement. Bereitschaftsmagnetfeld | url = | journal = Exp. Brain Res. | volume = 48 | issue = | pages = 144–148 | doi=10.1007/bf00239582}}</ref> It was confirmed that the early component, BP 1 or BF1, respectively was generated by the supplementary motor area (SMA), including the pre-SMA, while the late component, BP2 or BF2, was generated by the primary motor area, MI.
A very similar – and equally important – [[event-related potential]] (ERP) component had earlier been discovered by the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[neurophysiologist]] [[William Grey Walter]] in 1962 and published in 1964. It is the [[contingent negative variation]] (CNV).<ref name="Walteretal64">{{cite journal | last1 = Walter | first1 = W.G | last2 = Cooper | first2 = R. | last3 = Aldridge | first3 = V.J. | last4 = McCallum | first4 = W.C. | last5 = Winter | first5 = A.L. | year = 1964 | title = Contingent Negative Variation: an electric sign of sensorimotor association and expectancy in the human brain | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 203 | issue = | pages = 380–384 | doi=10.1038/203380a0 | pmid=14197376}}</ref><ref>Ray Cooper: ''The discovery of the contingent negative variation (CNV)'', In: ''Current Contents Life Sciences'' 21, May 27, 1985, [http://garfield.library.upenn.edu/classics1985/A1985AHJ7800001.pdf PDF]</ref> The CNV also composes two waves; the initial wave (i.e., O wave) and the terminal wave (i.e., E wave). The terminal CNV has similar characteristics as the BP and many researchers have claimed that the BP and the terminal CNV are the same component.<ref>Rohrbaugh, J.W.; Gaillard, A.W.K.: ''Sensory and motor aspects of the contingent negative variation''. In: A.W.K. Gaillard and W. Ritter (Eds.): ''Tutorials in Event Related Potential Research: Endogenous Components''. North Holland Publishing, Amsterdam 1983, {{ISBN|978-0-444-86551-9}}, pp. 269-310.</ref> At least there is a consensus that both indicate a preparation of the brain for a following behavior.<ref>Cornelis H. M. Brunia, Geert J. M. van Boxtel, Koen B. E. Böcker: ''Negative Slow Waves as Indices of Anticipation: The Bereitschaftspotential, the Contingent Negative Variation, and the Stimulus-Preceding Negativity''. In: Steven J. Luck, Emily S. Kappenman (Eds.): ''The Oxford Handbook of Event-Related Potential Components''. Oxford University Press, USA 2012, {{ISBN|0-19-537414-2}}, p. 189-207.</ref>
== Outcomes == The Bereitschaftspotential was received with great interest by the scientific community, as reflected by Sir John Eccles's comment: "There is a delightful parallel between these impressively simple experiments and the experiments of [[Galileo Galilei]] who investigated the laws of motion of the universe with metal balls on an inclined plane".<ref name="E&Z80">Eccles, J.C.; Zeier, H. (1980) ''Gehirn und Geist''. Zürich, Kindler.</ref> The interest was even greater in psychology and philosophy because volition is traditionally associated with human freedom (cf. Kornhuber 1984).<ref name="Kornhuber84">Kornhuber, H.H. (1984). Von der Freiheit pp 83–112 in Lindauer M, Schöpf A, eds., Wie erkennt der Mensch die Welt? Grundlagen des Erkennens, Fühlens und Handelns. Geistes und Naturwissenschaftler im Dialog. Ernst Klett Stuttgart.</ref> The spirit of the time, however, was hostile to freedom in those years; it was believed that freedom is an illusion. The tradition of behaviourism and Freudism was deterministic. While will and volition were frequently leading concepts in psychological research papers before and after the first world war and even during the second war, after the end of the second world war this declined, and by the mid-sixties these key words completely disappeared and were abolished in the thesaurus of the American Psychological Association.<ref name="Heckhausen87">Heckhausen, H. (1987). Perspektiven einer Psychologie des Wollens. pp 121–142 in Heckhausen, H. et al., eds., ''Jenseits des Rubikon: Der Wille in den Humanwissenschaften''. Springer, Berlin.</ref> The BP is an electrical sign of participation of the supplementary motor area (SMA) prior to volitional movement, which starts activity prior to the primary motor area.<ref name="D&K78">{{cite journal | last1 = Deecke | first1 = L | last2 = Kornhuber | first2 = H.H. | year = 1978 | title = An electrical sign of participation of the mesial "supplementary" motor cortex in human voluntary finger movement | url = | journal = Brain Res | volume = 159 | issue = | pages = 473–476 | doi=10.1016/0006-8993(78)90561-9 | pmid=728816}}</ref> The BP has precipitated a worldwide discussion about [[free will]] (cf. the closing chapter in the book "The Bereitschaftspotential").<ref name="D&K03">Deecke, L.; Kornhuber, H.H. (2003). Human freedom, reasoned will, and the brain. The Bereitschaftspotential story. In: M Jahanshahi, M Hallett (Eds.) ''The Bereitschaftspotential, movement-related cortical potentials''. Kluwer Academic / Plenum Publishers {{ISBN|0-306-47407-7}} pp. 283–320.</ref>
As said above, the activity of the SMA generates the early component of the Bereitschaftspotential (BP1 or BP early).<ref name="D38">{{cite journal | author = Deecke L, Kornhuber | year = 1978 | title = supplementary" motor cortex in human voluntary finger movements | url = | journal = Brain Res | volume = 159 | issue = 2| pages = 473–476 | doi=10.1016/0006-8993(78)90561-9| pmid = 728816 }}</ref> The SMA has the starting function of the movement or action. The role of the SMA was further substantiated by Cunnington et al. 2003,<ref name="D39">{{cite journal |vauthors=Cunnington R, Windischberger C, Deecke L, Moser E | year = 2003 | title = The preparation and readiness for voluntary movement: a high-field event-related fMRI study of the Bereitschafts-BOLD response | url = | journal = NeuroImage | volume = 20 | issue = 1| pages = 404–412 | doi=10.1016/s1053-8119(03)00291-x| pmid = 14527600 }}</ref> showing that SMA proper and pre-SMA are active prior to volitional movement or action, as well as the cingulate motor area (CMA). This is now called ‘anterior mid-cingulate cortex (aMCC)’. Recently it has been shown by integrating simultaneously acquired EEG and fMRI that SMA and aMCC have strong reciprocal connections that act to sustain each other’s activity, and that this interaction is mediated during movement preparation according to the Bereitschaftspotential amplitude.<ref name="D40">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nguyen VT, Breakspear M, Cunnington R | year = 2014 | title = Reciprocal interactions of the SMA and cingulate cortex sustain pre-movement activity for voluntary actions | url = | journal = J Neurosci | volume = 34 | issue = 49| pages = 16397–16407 | doi=10.1523/jneurosci.2571-14.2014| pmid = 25471577 }}</ref>
[[Electroencephalography|EEGs]] and [[Electromyography|EMGs]] are used in combination with [[Bayesian inference]] to construct [[Bayesian network]]s which attempt to predict general patterns of [[Motor Intent Neuron]] [[Action Potential]]s firing. Researchers attempting to develop non-intrusive [[brain-machine interface]]s are interested in this, as are system analysis, operations research, and epistemology (e.g. the Smith predictor has been suggested in the discussion). (explanation needed!)
=== BP and free will === In a series of experiments in the 1980s, [[Benjamin Libet]] studied the relationship between conscious experience of [[volition (psychology)|volition]] and the BP e.g.<ref name="Libet85">{{cite journal | last1 = Libet | first1 = B | year = 1985 | title = Unconscious cerebral initiative and the role of conscious will in voluntary action | url = | journal = Behav Brain Sci | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 529–566 | doi=10.1017/s0140525x00044903}}</ref> and found that the BP started about 0.35 sec ''earlier'' than the subject's reported conscious awareness that "now he or she feels the desire to make a movement." Libet concludes that we have no [[free will]] in the initiation of our movements; though, since subjects were able to prevent intended movement at the last moment, we do have the ability to veto these actions ("free won't").
These studies have provoked widespread debate.<ref name="L&dC10">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1007/s12152-009-9053-9|title=Not so Fast. On Some Bold Neuroscientific Claims Concerning Human Agency|journal=Neuroethics|volume=3|pages=23–41|year=2009|last1=Lavazza|first1=Andrea|last2=De Caro|first2=Mario}}</ref> See also the recent extensive critique by Klemm, 2010.<ref>Klemm, W. R. 2010 Free will debates: simple experiments are not so simple. "Advances in Cognitive Psychology,6: 47-65.</ref>
Kornhuber and Deecke have shown that we have free will also for the initiation of our movements and actions, not absolute freedom though, which would mean freedom from nature which is impossible but relative freedom—freedom in "degrees of freedom." According to Kornhuber and Deecke one can take efforts to increase one's degree of freedom through self-improvement, but one can also lose degrees of freedom through self-mismanagement, see below under "further reading" at third position Kornhuber and Deecke (2012).
In 2016, a group around [[John-Dylan Haynes]] in Berlin (Germany) determined the time window after the BP in which an intended motion could possibly be cancelled upon command.<ref name="PMID26668390">{{Cite journal|pmc=4743787|year=2016|author1=Schultze-Kraft|first1=M|title=The point of no return in vetoing self-initiated movements|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=113|issue=4|pages=1080–1085|last2=Birman|first2=D|last3=Rusconi|first3=M|last4=Allefeld|first4=C|last5=Görgen|first5=K|last6=Dähne|first6=S|last7=Blankertz|first7=B|last8=Haynes|first8=J. D.|doi=10.1073/pnas.1513569112|pmid=26668390}}</ref> The authors tested whether human volunteers could win a “duel“ against a BCI (Brain Computer Interface) designed to predict their movements in real-time from observations of their EEG activity (the BP). They aimed to determine the exact time at which cancellation (veto) of movements was not possible anymore (the point of no return). The computer was trained to predict by means of the BP when a proband would move. The point of no return was at 200 ms before the movement. However, even after that, when a pedal was already set in motion, the subjects were able to reschedule their action by not completing the already started behavior. The authors pointed out in their report that cancellation of self-initiated movements had already been reported by Libet in 1985. Thus, the new achievement was a more precise determination of the point of no return.
== Applications == An interesting use of the Bereitschaftspotential is in [[Brain-Computer Interface]] (BCI) applications; this signal feature can be identified from scalp recording (even from single-trial measurements) and interpreted for various uses, for example control of computer displays or control of peripheral motor units in spinal cord injuries.<ref name="Wangetal04">{{cite journal | last1 = Wang | first1 = Y. | last2 = Zhang | first2 = Z. | last3 = Li | first3 = Y. | last4 = Gao | first4 = X. | last5 = Gao | first5 = S. | last6 = Yang | first6 = F. | year = 2004 | title = BCI competition 2003-data set IV: An algorithm based on CSSD and FDA for classifying single-trial EEG | url = | journal = IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering | volume = 51 | issue = 6| pages = 1081–1086 | doi=10.1109/tbme.2004.826697}}</ref> The most important BCI application is the 'mental' steering of artificial limbs in amputees.

{{refimprove|date=August 2018}} {{expert needed|1=Computer science|date=August 2018}} '''Brighterion''' (est. in 2000) is an [[artificial intelligence]] company owned by [[MasterCard]]. == History==
Dr. Akli Adjaoute, while finishing his PhD in Artficial Intelligence <ref>{{Cite news|url= http://www.worldcat.org/title/rylm-generateur-de-systemes-experts-pour-les-problemes-daide-aux-diagnostics-ykra-systeme-denseignement/oclc/490376189|title=PhD in Artificial Intelligence ( DOCTORAT D’ETAT) |language=en-US}}</ref> at [[Pierre and Marie Curie University|Pierre and Marie Curie University]], founded his first company, Conception En Intelligence Artificielle in 1988 in Paris, France where he was able to successfully apply his years of research in the field of artificial intelligence in various industries throughout Europe. Conception En Intelligence Artificielle initially offered Rylm, a platform (MINDsuite) based on Smart Agents, Neural Networks, Business Rules, Genetic Algorithms, Constraint Programming, Fuzzy Logic and Cased-based Reasoning.
Rylm’s first application was in the decommissioning of nuclear facilities and [[nuclear waste management|Radioactive waste]]. This application was led by the team that invented the programming language [[Prolog|PROLOG]] and is described in the [http://brighterion.com/articles/rylm_nuclear.pdf Radioactive Waste Handling Operations paper]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://brighterion.com/articles/rylm_nuclear.pdf|title=Radioactive Waste Handling Operations paper|language=en-US}}</ref>.
Rylm’s second application was in healthcare at Necker Hospital as highlighted by the French magazine [http://brighterion.com/articles/rylm_healthcare.pdf L’Usine Nouvelle Technologies]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://brighterion.com/articles/rylm_healthcare.pdf|title=L’Usine Nouvelle Technologies|language=en-US}}</ref>.
Another application of Rylm was in network troubleshooting as described in the French magazine [https://web.archive.org/web/20170813104157/http:/brighterion.com/articles/rylm_network_troubleshooting.pdf 01 Informatique]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170813104157/http:/brighterion.com/articles/rylm_network_troubleshooting.pdf|title=01 Informatique|language=en-US}}</ref>.
The technology behind Rylm was also successfully applied in various other fields including: financials, supply chain, retail, and military.
Rylm has received recognition for its industry-leading technology including mention in the Meta Group report [https://web.archive.org/web/20170429211729/http:/brighterion.com/articles/rylm_metagroup_datamining.pdf Data Mining Market]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170429211729/http:/brighterion.com/articles/rylm_metagroup_datamining.pdf|title= Meta Group report Data Mining Market|language=en-US}}</ref> for best [[Machine learning|Machine Learning]] Technology.
In 2000, this technology formed the foundation of Brighterion, Inc. and in 2002, [[Raymond Kendall|Raymond Kendall]], three-time Secretary General of [[Interpol|INTERPOL]] joined the company as its chairman. Since the founding of Brighterion, the core technology has been adapted and improved for real-time applications in the fields of homeland security, payment, compliance, IoT, healthcare, and marketing.
Brighterion has received multiple awards including: the Payment Security Excellence Award, the 2017 Cool Vendor by Gartner, Inc.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.gartner.com/doc/reprints?id=1-413QTFK&ct=170524&st=sb|title=Cool Vendors in Identity and Fraud Management, 2017|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-gb}}</ref> and the Morgan Stanley Fintech Award<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.morganstanley.com/press-releases/morgan-stanley-recognizes-brighterion-with-fintech-award-at-firm|title=Morgan Stanley Recognizes Brighterion with Fintech Award at Firm’s Annual Fintech Summit 7|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-gb}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tomgroenfeldt/2017/11/20/brighterion-anti-fraud-software-wins-morgan-stanley-first-fintech-award/|title=Brighterion's Artificial Intelligence Software Wins Morgan Stanley's First Fintech Award|author=Tom Groenfeldt|date=2017-11-20|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=2018-08-09}}</ref>.
Brighterion holds several patents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://patents.justia.com/assignee/brighterion-inc|title=Brighterion's patents|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-gb}}</ref>
In August 2017, [[Mastercard]] acquired Brighterion<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nasdaq.com/article/mastercard-to-buy-brighterion-boost-artificial-intelligence-cm817435|title=Nasdaq : Mastercard to Buy Brighterion, Boost Artificial Intelligence|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-gb}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newsroom.mastercard.com/press-releases/mastercard-enhances-artificial-intelligence-capability-with-the-acquisition-of-brighterion-inc-2/|title=Mastercard Enhances Artificial Intelligence Capability with the Acquisition of Brighterion, Inc.|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref>.

{{Orphan|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox laboratory equipment |name = Cancer Personalized Profiling by deep Sequencing |acronym = CAPP-Seq |uses = Quantification of low level ctDNA from cancer patients. |notable_experiments = CAPP-Seq was applied on non–small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) to identify recurrent somatic alterations from ctDNA. |inventors = Diehn, Alizadeh, Newman, Bratman |year = 2014 |related = [[Cell-free tumour DNA]] }} '''CAncer Personalized Profiling by deep Sequencing (CAPP-Seq)''' is a sensitive method used to quantify DNA in [[cancer]]. It measures [[Cell-free tumour DNA|Cell-free tumor DNA]] which is released from dead tumor cells into the blood. This method can be generalized for any cancer type that is known to have recurrent mutations.<ref name="Newman">{{cite journal|last1=Newman|first1=Aaron M|title=An ultrasensitive method for quantitating circulating tumor DNA with broad patient coverage|journal=Nature Medicine|date=2014|volume=20|issue=548|pmid=24705333|doi=10.1038/nm.3519|pmc=4016134|pages=548–54}}<!--|accessdate=25 February 2016--></ref> CAPP-Seq can detect one molecule of mutant DNA in 10,000 molecules of healthy DNA.
CAPP-Seq was designed to lower sequencing costs by only targeting specific areas of the genome that are recurrently mutated for a given cancer. This allows for sequencing costs between $200-$300 USD. It can also target multiple areas of the genome at once and a variety of different types of mutations, allowing for a lower amount of input DNA compared to other methods.
==Methods==
[[File:Wiki figure updated5.pdf|thumb|upright=2.6|'''Figure 01:''' An overview of the workflow of CAPP-Seq.]]
Population analysis is performed to identify recurrent mutations in a given cancer type. This is done by analyzing public data sets such as the [[COSMIC cancer database]] and [[The Cancer Genome Atlas|TCGA]]. A ‘selector’ is designed which consists of [[biotin]]ylated DNA oligonucleotide probes targeting the recurrently mutated regions chosen for the specific cancer type. The selector is chosen using a multiphase bioinformatics approach. Using the selector, a probe-based hybridization capture is performed on tumor and normal DNA to discover mutations specific to the patient. The hybridization capture is then also applied to ctDNA to quantify the mutations that were previously discovered.<ref name="Newman" />
===ctDNA Extraction and Library Preparation=== Peripheral blood is collected from patients and ctDNA is isolated from ≥1 mL of [[Blood plasma|plasma]]. DNA libraries are made using the KAPA Library kit with some modifications in order to optimize protocols for use with ctDNA. The KAPA HiFi polymerase is used here because it is the most effective and produces the fewest number of errors. Input DNA can be as low as 4 ng.<ref name="Newman" />
There were four main goals in adapting this protocol for ctDNA work:
*1) to optimize the adapter ligation efficiency *2) to reduce the number of PCR cycles needed after ligation *3) to preserve the naturally occurring size distribution of ctDNA (median 170 bit/s) *4) to minimize the variability in depth of sequence coverage across all the captured regions
These were achieved by allowing adaptor ligation to be carried out at 16℃ for 16 hours to increase adaptor ligation efficiency and recovery. The most important adaptation is during enzymatic and clean-up steps; they are performed with-bead, in order to minimize tube transfer steps which increases recovery.
===Selector design===
In CAPP-Seq, design of selector is a crucial step that identifies recurrent mutations in a particular cancer type using publicly available next generation sequencing data. For inclusion in CAPP-seq selector, the recurrent mutations that are enriched in a population is described by an index- [[Recurrence Index]] (RI). RI is the number of mutations per kilobase of a given genomic locus of a patient carrying particular mutations. RI represents a patient level recurrence frequency estimated for somatic mutations and all mutations. Known and driver recurrent mutations in a population can be ranked based on the RI and therefore RI is used to design a selector. A six phase design strategy is employed to design selector.<ref name="Newman" />
*Phase-1: Identifying frequently mutated known driver mutations using the publicly available data. *Phase-2: Maximum coverage of SNVs among the patients was identified by ranking their exonic RI. *Phase-3 and 4: Exons with higher RI were selected. *Phase-5: Addition of previously predicted driver mutations. *Phase-6: Addition of recurrent gene fusions rearrangement that are specific for particular cancer.
Human cancer is heterogeneous and recurrent cancer mutations are present only a minority of patient. Therefore, a careful and non-redundant design of selector is the vital part in CAPP-Seq and also the size of the selector is related to its downstream costs.
[[File:Capp-seq capture of DNA.pdf|thumb|upright=1.5|'''Figure 02:''' Hybridization capture protocol used in CAPP-Seq.]]
===Hybridization Capture and Sequencing===
Hybridization capture with the selector probe set is performed on tumor DNA from a biopsy and sequenced to a depth of ~10,000× coverage. The biotinylated selector probes bind selectively to the regions of the DNA library that were chosen to be where the recurrently mutations occur in the given cancer type. In this way you are left with a smaller library that is enriched for only the regions you want, which can then be sequenced. This allows the determination of patient specific mutations. Hybridization capture with the same selector is then performed on ctDNA from the blood to quantify the previously identified mutations in the patient. CAPP-Seq can be applied to ctDNA from multiple blood samples at different time points in order to follow tumor evolution.
==Computational pipeline for CAPP-seq== A series of steps are involved in analysis of CAPP-Seq data from mutation detection to validation and open source software can do most of the analysis. After the first step of variant calling, germline and [[loss of heterozygosity]] (LOH) mutations are removed in CAPP-seq to reduce the background biases. Several statistical significance tests can be performed against background to all type of variant calling. For example, statistical significance of tumor-derived SNVs can be estimated by random sampling of background alleles using [[Monte Carlo method]]. For the indel calls, statistical significance is calculated applying a separate method that used a strand specific analysis by [[Z-test]] shown in previous work.<ref name="Newman" /> Finally, a computational validation steps reduces the false positive calls. However, a robust computational framework specific for CAPP-seq data analysis is a high demand in this field.
==Sensitivity== Sensitivity of this technology depends on the effective design of selector and highly biased with the size of the cohort and type of cancer under study. The lack of background to find the statistically significant recurrent variants has limited its performance due to stochastic noise and biological variability. [[Receiver Operating Characteristic]] (ROC) analysis on several cancer patient and cancer cured patient (sample collected at different tumor stages, circulating DNA time point, treatment, etc.) showed that CAPP-seq has higher sensitivity and specificity compared to previous methods in non–small-cell lung cancer.<ref name="Newman" />
==Limitations==
The detection limit of CAPP-Seq is affected by three main areas: the input amount of ctDNA molecules, sample cross-contamination, potential allelic bias in the capture reagent, and [[PCR]] or sequencing errors. CtDNA is able to be detected at a lower limit of 0.025% fractional abundance in the blood. Sample cross-contamination was found to be a very small contribution and reports have shown minimal allelic bias towards capture of reference alleles in PBLs ([[peripheral blood lymphocytes]]). PCR and sequencing errors are also minimal.<ref name="Newman" />
It is important to note that when using CAPP-Seq on ctDNA it still currently not known whether ctDNA is released at equal rates from primary tumors and [[metastatic disease]], so this should be taken into consideration. This could cause problems with determining tumor burden and clonal evolution if different tumors or clones are dying off and releasing their DNA at different rates. It is also unknown how tumor histology affects ctDNA release.
Another major limitation with only using ctDNA levels to detect tumor burden is that ctDNA can only predict residual tumor, it cannot tell you where the tumor or tumors are located within the body. This means that ctDNA will be best used complementary to imaging for disease burden at this time.
==Advantages==
CAPP-Seq has many advantages over other methods such as [[digital polymerase chain reaction]] (dPCR) and [[amplicon]] sequencing. CAPP-Seq can survey many loci in the same experiment compared to dPCR and amplicon sequencing which use multiple different experiments and therefore use up much more sample. Another advantage is that CAPP-Seq can not only detect point mutations but it can also detect [[indels]], [[structural variations]], and [[copy number variations]].<ref name="Bratman">{{cite journal|last1=Bratman|first1=Scott V.|title=Potential clinical utility of ultrasensitive circulating tumor DNA detection with CAPP-Seq|journal=Expert review of molecular diagnostics|date=2015|volume=15|issue=6|pages=715–719|pmid=25773944|doi=10.1586/14737159.2015.1019476|pmc=5052032}}</ref>
Another advantage of CAPP-Seq is that because it only targets specific areas of interest in the genome it is more cost effective than whole [[exome sequencing]] and [[whole genome sequencing]] which are 171X and 44X more expensive respectively.<ref name="Newman" />
Using circulating tumor DNA as opposed to solid tumor biopsies allows analysis of the full repertoire of tumor cells dispersed throughout the tumor and distant metastasis. Therefore, there is a better chance of finding all mutations associated with this cancer. Having a full overview of the cancer and what is driving it will allow for better treatment plans and management of disease.
==Applications==
===Monitoring tumor burden=== When treating cancer it is useful to have precise measurements of the total body disease burden. It helps with determining prognostic significance and treatment response. This is normally done using computed tomography ([[CT scans]]), positron emission tomography ([[PET scans]]) or magnetic resonance imaging ([[MRI]]).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bar-Shalom|title=Clinical performance of PET/CT in evaluation of cancer: additional value for diagnostic imaging and patient management.|journal=J Nucl Med|date=2003|volume=44|issue=8|pages=1200–9.|pmid=12902408}}</ref> These medical imaging procedures are expensive and are not without their own problems. These imaging techniques are not able to accurately resolve small tumors (≤1 cm in diameter).<ref name="Bratman" /> Imaging can also be affected by radiation-induced inflammation and fibrotic changes, making is hard to determine if there is residual tumor or just effects of treatment.<ref name="Newman" />
It has been found that levels of ctDNA in plasma significantly correlate with tumor volume as compare with medical imaging (CT, PET and MRI).,<ref name="Newman" /><ref name="Bratman" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diehl|first1=Frank|title=Circulating mutant DNA to assess tumor dynamics|journal=Nature Medicine|date=2007|volume=14|pages=985–990|pmid=18670422|doi=10.1038/nm.1789|pmc=2820391}}</ref><ref name="Scherer">{{cite journal|last1=Scherer|first1=Florian Scherer|title=Noninvasive Genotyping and Assessment of Treatment Response in Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma|journal=Blood|date=2015|volume=126|issue=23}}</ref> Detection of ctDNA can predict residual tumor or imminent relapse, in some cases even better than medical imaging and current methods.
===Prognostic indicator=== Detection of ctDNA has been found to be a predictor of relapse in multiple studies thus far. In a study <ref name="Bratman" /> in late stage [[NSCLC]] (non-small cell lung cancer) they found two cases where ctDNA correctly determined the outcome of a patient when medical imaging was wrong. In one cause, the imaging predicted relapse based on a suspected residual tumor which turned out to only be radiation induced inflammation, but ctDNA was not detected and the patient did not relapse. In another case, the imaging showed no tumor but ctDNA was detected and the patient relapsed shortly afterwards. In another study <ref name="Scherer" /> on [[DLBCL]] (diffuse large B cell lymphoma), ctDNA was also found to be predictive of relapse.
===Biopsy-free tumor genotyping=== Biopsies are invasive and associated with risks to the patient. Therefore, multiple biopsies to monitor disease progression are rare and diagnostic biopsies are relied on for genetic information. This can be problematic because of tumor heterogeneity and tumor evolution. Firstly, biopsies only sample one portion of the tumor, and because tumors are heterogeneous, this will not cover the full genetic landscape of the tumor. Secondly, after treatment tumors evolve and there may be new mutations not represented in the diagnostic sample.<ref name="Newman" /><ref name="Bratman" />
Biopsy-free tumor genotyping, by way of CAPP-Seq and ctDNA, addresses many of these issues. A simple blood test is non-invasive and much safer and easier to subject cancer patients to multiple times through the course of treatment. Using ctDNA gives a better sample of tumor DNA compared to a single area of a tumor collected in a biopsy, allowing a better estimate of tumor heterogeneity. Taking multiple samples of ctDNA at different time points following the course of treatment allows tumor evolution to be uncovered. This can help detect the emergence of mutations that confer resistance to a targeted therapy and allow the course of treatment to be adjusted accordingly. CAPP-Seq specifically allows for the screening of multiple genomic locations which will become important as the list of cancer mutations important for treatment continues to grow.<ref name="Bratman" /> In a study<ref name="Newman" /> for late stage NSCLC, they performed a version of CAPP-Seq where the tumor biopsy was not sequenced first, and they were able to correctly classify 100% of patient plasma samples with a 0% false positive rate. This shows that even without previous knowledge of tumor mutations, they can be accurately discovered by ctDNA alone.
