==Canada== *[[Kenneth Zeller]], a gay man in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] who was employed as a schoolteacher, was murdered by five young offenders in [[High Park]] in 1985. The incident spurred the [[Toronto District School Board]] to implement a program to combat anti-gay discrimination and violence — culminating in the creation of the [[Triangle Program]], Canada's first [[alternative school]] program for at-risk LGBT youth, in 1995.<ref>Alanna Mitchell, "Welcome to Canada's gay high school: Toronto's Triangle program offers an educational refuge". ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', May 29, 2004.</ref> *On March 19, 1989, Joe Rose, a young gay activist in [[Montreal]], was [[stabbing|stabbed]] to death by a gang of teenagers who targeted him for having pink hair. The incident later inspired educator Michael Whatling, who had been a classmate of Rose's at the time of his death, to publish ''[[A Vigil for Joe Rose]]'', an exploration of the struggles faced by LGBT students.<ref>[http://pre2010.thelinknewspaper.ca/articles/1887 "High school homos"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120725222205/http://pre2010.thelinknewspaper.ca/articles/1887 |date=2012-07-25 }}. ''[[The Link (newspaper)|The Link]]'', November 17, 2009, p. 8.</ref> *On August 21, 1989, Alain Brosseau, a straight man in [[Ottawa]], was attacked by a gang of teenagers who wrongly assumed him to be gay, while walking home from his job at the [[Château Laurier]].<ref name=brosseau>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2009/08/21/ottawa-alain-brosseau-ceremony.html "Gay-targeted murder recalled 20 years later"]. [[CBC News]], August 21, 2009.</ref> The attackers chased him through [[Major's Hill Park]] to the [[Alexandra Bridge]], and then threw him off the bridge resulting in his death.<ref name="brosseau"/> This resulted in a gay and lesbian community outcry and eventually led to the formation of the [[Ottawa Police Service]]'s GLBT Liaison Committee two years later.<ref name=brosseau /> * [[Aaron Webster]], a gay man in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], was beaten to death with baseball bats and pool cues on November 17, 2001 in a part of [[Stanley Park]] known for [[Cruising for sex|cruising]]. Ryan Cran, along with two unidentified youths, was convicted of manslaughter in Webster's death. Cran was paroled in February 2009 after serving four years of a six-year sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/02/05/bc-arron-webster-ryan-cran-released.html |title=Gay community troubled by release of killer in Stanley Park death |work=CBC News |date=February 5, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090416164904/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2009/02/05/bc-arron-webster-ryan-cran-released.html |archivedate=April 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> * Conner Copeman, 20 of [[Cumberland, British Columbia]] was assaulted in [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]] on July 11, 2007 by a group of men in a park in the city's [[Buena Vista, Saskatoon|Buena Vista]] neighbourhood. Copeman had recently moved to the city, and confessed to police that he was flirting with some men, who later attacked him. Copeman was found laying in the street six blocks east of the park, with a broken neck. Copeman ended up a [[quadriplegic]] as a result of his injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/paralyzed-man-helps-police-reopen-assault-case-1.1184996|title=Paralyzed man helps police reopen assault case|df=}}</ref> * Jordan Smith, 27, of [[White Rock, British Columbia]], was assaulted on September 27, 2008 by 20-year-old Michael Kandola of Vancouver. Smith was holding hands with another male while walking in Vancouver's [[Davie Village]], an area frequented by [[GLBTQ]] individuals, when Kandola started following the pair with four to five of his friends and began shouting anti-gay obscenities towards the gay pair. Kandola confronted the two and punched Smith on the side of his head, knocking him unconscious. Smith required surgery for his injuries. Kandola was charged with assault causing bodily harm, and police sought to invoke Canadian hate-crime legislation against Kandola. A [[Facebook]] group with over 4000 members was established petitioning for a minimum life imprisonment sentence for Kandola.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/story.html?id=c8585fc3-b8af-4d0a-8280-e80bff7d48da|title=Vancouver Police Seek Hate Charge|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311011108/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/story.html?id=c8585fc3-b8af-4d0a-8280-e80bff7d48da|archivedate=2012-03-11|df=}}</ref> On April 30, 2010, the assault was deemed by the B.C. Supreme Court to be a hate crime and Kandola was sentenced to 17 months in jail.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2010/04/30/bc-kandola-sentence.html#ixzz0oV9OD0hD |title=BC gay basher gets 17-month sentence |work=CBC News |date=April 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504132600/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/british-columbia/story/2010/04/30/bc-kandola-sentence.html |archivedate=May 4, 2010 }}</ref> * Anji Dimitriou and Jane Currie were physically assaulted on November 3, 2008 at an [[Oshawa]], [[Ontario]] public school while waiting to pick up their children. Mark Scott, the attacker, punched both women in the face, referring to them as "men", "fucking dyke bitches" and spit in Dimitriou's face. He was in court in January 2009, for two counts of assault causing bodily harm.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/toronto/archive/2008/12/09/no-hate-charges-in-attack-on-oshawa-lesbians.aspx|title=No hate charges in attack on Oshawa lesbians}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081112/oshawa_attack_081112/20081112/|title=Lesbians seek hate crime charges after attack}}</ref> However, the incident was prosecuted as a simple assault and not as a [[hate crime]], as Scott neither advocated [[genocide]] nor incited anyone else to join in the attack.<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/article/550852 "No hate crimes charges in lesbian assault"], ''[[Toronto Star]]'', December 9, 2008.</ref> *On March 13, 2009, Shawn Woodward was charged with aggravated assault after physically attacking 62-year-old Ritchie Dowrey in [[Vancouver]]'s [[Fountainhead Pub]], allegedly because "He's a faggot. He deserved it."<ref>Jeremy Hainsworth, [http://www.xtra.ca/public/Vancouver/Community_members_demand_court_treat_Fountainhead_gaybashing_as_a_hate_crime-6519.aspx "Community members demand court treat Fountainhead gaybashing as a hate crime"]. ''[[Xtra! West]]'', March 26, 2009.</ref> Dowrey had briefly bumped into Woodward's shoulder, which the heterosexual Woodward characterized during his trial as a predatory sexual advance.<ref name=woodwardguilty>[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/british-columbia/man-found-guilty-in-vancouver-gay-bashing-case/article1669511/ "Man found guilty in Vancouver gay-bashing case"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', August 11, 2010.</ref> Although Dowrey survived the assault, he suffered serious and permanent brain damage, and spent the entire rest of his life living in care facilities until his death in 2015.<ref>[http://www.theprovince.com/life/tragic+Ritch+Dowrey+victim+violent+2009+West+bashing+dies/10779164/story.html "'A tragic day': Ritch Dowrey, victim of violent 2009 West End gay bashing, dies"]. ''[[The Province]]'', February 2, 2015.</ref> At Woodward's trial, Justice Jocelyn Palmer rejected the allegation that Dowrey had groped Woodward, ultimately finding that "[Woodward's] intention was to deny, deflect and dissemble. He fabricated this story to justify his outrageous assault."<ref name=woodwardguilty /> *On October 18, 2010, the home of a gay couple in [[Little Pond, Prince Edward Island|Little Pond]], [[Prince Edward Island]] was [[firebombing|firebombed]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/canada/prince-edward-island/story/2010/11/03/pe-human-rights-defend-gay-couple.html "Support grows for gay fire victims"]. [[cbc.ca]], November 4, 2010.</ref> Both men escaped the fire unharmed, but their home was destroyed. In late October and November, a series of rallies and fundraising concerts was held in both Little Pond and [[Charlottetown]] to support the couple and to oppose homophobic violence.<ref>[http://www.xtra.ca/public/National/Gay_couple_burned_from_PEI_home-9470.aspx "Gay couple burned from PEI home"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129024734/http://www.xtra.ca/public/National/Gay_couple_burned_from_PEI_home-9470.aspx# |date=2010-11-29 }}. ''[[Xtra!]]'', November 24, 2010.</ref> *On April 17, 2012, [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]] gay activist Raymond Taavel was beaten to death outside Menz & Mollyz, a gay bar on the city's Göttingen Street, by Andre Denny, a paranoid schizophrenic on an unsupervised leave from a nearby forensic hospital for those found Not Criminally Responsible for previous unlawful activity, after attempting to break up a fight between Denny and another man.<ref name=taavel>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/story/2012/04/21/ns-taavel-fundraiser.html "Fundraiser planned in memory of N.S. gay activist"]. [[CBC News]], April 21, 2012.</ref> Taavel was a former chair of [[Halifax Pride]], the city's [[gay pride]] festival, and a former editor at the LGBT magazine ''[[Wayves]]'' and the spiritual magazine ''[[Lion's Roar (magazine)|Lion's Roar]]''.<ref name=taavel /> Over 1,000 people attended a vigil in Taavel's memory later the same evening, which included performances by poet [[Tanya Davis]], actor and writer Stewart Legere and singer-songwriters [[Rose Cousins]] and [[Ria Mae]].<ref>[http://www.xtra.ca/public/National/Haligonians_gather_to_remember_Raymond_Taavel-11859.aspx "Haligonians gather to remember Raymond Taavel"]. ''[[Xtra!]]'', April 17, 2012.</ref> Although there were unconfirmed allegations that Denny used anti-gay slurs while attacking Taavel,<ref name=taavelreleased>[http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/04/18/man-accused-of-murdering-gay-activist-raymond-taavel-should-never-have-been-released-lawyer/ "Man accused of murdering gay activist Raymond Taavel should never have been released: lawyer"]. ''[[National Post]]'', April 18, 2012.</ref> to date media and the police have not asserted that the case clearly constituted a hate crime, generally attributing the attack to Denny's mental illness rather than to a specifically anti-gay bias.<ref name=taavelreleased /> Ironically, Taavel had previously survived a more clearly anti-gay physical attack, which he wrote about in ''Wayves'' in May 2010.<ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/2012/04/17/halifax-murder-victim-raymond-taavel-had-a-lovely-joyous-presence/ "Halifax murder victim Raymond Taavel had a ‘lovely, joyous presence’"]. ''[[National Post]]'', April 17, 2012.</ref> *On September. 30, 2012, [[New Westminister, British Columbia]]: January Marie Lapuz, 26, was found in her home in the 500 block of Third Avenue around 10 p.m. Sept. 30, 2012 suffering from stab wounds. She died the next morning at Royal Columbian Hospital. Charles Jameson Neel, 22, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in June in her stabbing death and was sentenced to eight years in prison. Lapuz was the first transgender person on the executive of Sher Vancouver, an organization supporting gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender South Asians. She was named the organization's social coordinator, according to its website in 2012.<ref name=lapuz_nwnl>[http://www.newwestnewsleader.com/news/277964361.html"New Westminster transgendered [sic] woman's killer gets eight years" ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129063835/http://www.newwestnewsleader.com/news/277964361.html |date=2014-11-29 }}. [[new west news leader]], Oct 2, 2014.</ref><ref name=lapuz_ctv>[http://bc.ctvnews.ca/guilty-plea-in-killing-of-transgender-woman-in-new-westminster-1.1860355"]. [[CTV News]], June 9, 2014.</ref> *On October 12, 2013 Scott Jones, a gay resident of [[New Glasgow, Nova Scotia|New Glasgow]], [[Nova Scotia]], was stabbed by a knife-wielding man after leaving the Acro Lounge.<ref name=jones>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/scott-jones-says-he-was-attacked-for-being-gay-1.2459289 "Scott Jones said he was attacked for being gay"]. [[CBC News]], December 11, 2013.</ref> He was left [[paraplegic]] by the attack.<ref name=jones /> His attacker, Shane Matheson, was found guilty and sentenced to 10 years in prison in June 2014.<ref name=matheson>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/scott-jones-says-he-forgives-his-attacker-shane-edward-matheson-1.2673052 "Scott Jones says he forgives his attacker, Shane Edward Matheson"]. [[CBC News]], June 12, 2014.</ref> During his recovery, Jones participated in the creation of Don't Be Afraid, a province-wide campaign to combat homophobia,<ref name=halifaxpride>[http://dailyxtra.com/canada/news/halifax-pride-names-scott-jones-grand-marshal "Halifax Pride names Scott Jones grand marshal"]. ''[[Xtra!]]'', July 6, 2014.</ref> and was selected as the grand marshal of the 2014 [[Halifax Pride]] parade.<ref name=halifaxpride /> He was profiled in the 2018 documentary film ''[[Love, Scott]]''.<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/radio/thecurrent/the-current-for-april-27-2018-1.4637146/after-surviving-attack-scott-jones-chronicles-the-lifelong-process-of-forgiveness-1.4637282 "After surviving attack, Scott Jones chronicles the 'lifelong process' of forgiveness"]. ''[[The Current (radio program)|The Current]]'', April 27, 2018.</ref>
==Chile== * [[Daniel Zamudio]], [[Chilean people|Chilean]] [[gay]] man who was tortured and murdered in [[Santiago]] in 2012 after his attackers learned of his [[sexual orientation]].<ref name="The Week 2013">The Week, "International News: Hate Crime Punished," November 8, 2013.</ref> After his murder he has become a symbol against [[Violence against LGBT people|homophobic violence]] in Chile, and his death and all the media attention contributed to accelerating legislation against discrimination, as well as opening new doors of acceptance and tolerance of differences in the conservative country.
==Croatia== * 30 participants at a [[gay pride]] event in [[Croatia]] were attacked by multiple assailants on July 7, 2007. The attackers had also prepared [[Molotov cocktail]]s but were stopped by the police before using them. Many people taking part in Gay Pride marches in [[Eastern Europe]] (e.g.: [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Serbia]]) have been beaten after leaving the marches.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/10/30/europe/EU-GEN-Croatia-Hate-Crime.php|title=Croat charged with hate crime for attempting to attack gay parade|publisher=[[International Herald Tribune]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mywire.com/pubs/AFP/2007/07/07/3921947?extID=10051|title=Violence at Croatian Gay Pride march}}</ref>
==France== [[File:Wilfred De Bruijn wounded - Same-sex Marriage in France.JPG|thumb|Wilfred De Bruijn on April 7, 2013.]] * Francois Chenu was murdered (beaten and drowned) by [[white power skinhead|neo-Nazi skinheads]] on September 13, 2002, in Reims, France. The murder became the subject of the documentary ''[[Beyond Hatred]],'' which includes extended interviews with members of Francois' family during and after the trial. As depicted in the documentary, one of the assailants was a minor, who received a 15-year sentence, while two adult attackers received 20-year sentences. The parents of the 15-year-old also received 6-month sentences for their neglect, contributing to their son's violence. * [[Bertrand Delanoë]], the openly gay mayor of [[Paris]], was non-fatally stabbed by a Muslim immigrant, Azedine Berkane, in October 2002. * Alexis Frumin was murdered June 9, 2007 in [[Reims]] by white power skinheads motivated by hatred of his ethnicity and sexual orientation.<ref>http://www.lunion.presse.fr/article/marne/affaire-frumin-un-crime-raciste-et-homophobe</ref> * Wilfred de Bruijn was beaten while walking with his boyfriend in the [[19th arrondissement of Paris]] on April 7, 2013. de Bruijn later posted a photograph of his badly injured face on [[Facebook]] to raise awareness of homophobic attacks, attracting international media attention in the process.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/10/wilfred-de-bruijn-france-gay-attack-_n_3055836.html | work=Huffington Post | title=Anti-Gay Attack Victim Becomes French Icon | date=April 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2307288/Paris-gay-attack-victim-Wilfred-Bruijns-Facebook-injuries-picture-goes-viral.html | location=London | work=Daily Mail | title='This is the true face of homophobia': Gay man viciously beaten in Paris posts picture of his injuries to Facebook in protest move that has now gone viral}}</ref> The attack was led by an ethnic gang.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.liberation.fr/societe/2014/06/03/prison-ferme-pour-deux-des-agresseurs-d-un-couple-gay_1032056 | location=Paris | work=Libération | title=' Prison ferme pour deux des agresseurs d'un couple gay '}}</ref>
==Iraq== * In 2005, the [[Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani]] issued a [[fatwa]] on his website calling for the execution of gays in the "worst, most severe way". Following protests from UK-based Iraqi gay rights groups, Sistani agreed to remove the fatwa from his website except for the section calling for the punishment of lesbianism. In January 2007, a [[United Nations]] report described the increased persecution, torture and extrajudicial killing of Iraqi lesbians and gay men by the [[Shia]] [[death squads]] of the [[Badr Organization|Badr]] and [[Sadrist Movement|Sadr]] militias (the armed wings of the two main Shia parties that control the government of Iraq).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iraqi-police-killed-14yearold-boy-for-being-homosexual-476917.html|title=Iraqi police 'killed 14-year-old boy for being homosexual'|publisher=[[The Independent]] | location=London|first=Jerome|last=Taylor|date=May 5, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/18/world/middleeast/18baghdad.html?_r=1&oref=slogin|title=Gays Living in Shadows of New Iraq|publisher=[[New York Times]] | first=Cara|last=Buckley|date=December 18, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/politics/2005-1476.html|title=Iraqi Ayatollah removes gay fatwa|publisher=Pink News}}</ref>
==Ireland== * Charlie Self, a 33-year-old set designer at the TV network [[RTÉ]] and a well-known member of the gay community in Dublin, was stabbed fourteen times in his apartment on 21 January 1982. Nobody has been brought to justice for the killing. It has been alleged in the press that homophobia on the part of the police may have led to a lack of willingness to pursue justice against Self's killer. In 2011 the case was reinvestigated as part of a cold cases review.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/garda-homophobia-played-a-part-in-the-failure-to-solve-case-26748125.html|title=Garda homophobia played a part in the failure to solve case|first=Jim|last=Cusack|date=3 July 2011|work=Irish Independent}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/cold-case-gardai-may-be-close-to-solving-rte-murder-156525-Jun2011/|title=Cold case: Gardaí may be close to solving RTÉ man's murder|work=thejournal.ie|date=15 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.herald.ie/news/two-fresh-leads-as-cold-case-team-open-rte-killing-27980422.html|title=Two fresh leads as cold case team open RTE killing|first=Ken|last=Foy|work=TheHerald.ie|date=20 May 2011}}</ref> * [[Declan Flynn]] was beaten to death in [[Fairview, Dublin|Fairview Park]], [[Dublin]], in 1983. The murder and subsequent suspended sentences of the perpetrators who pleaded guilty to murder saw the emergence of a more vocal gay community in the aftermath.<ref name="Scanlan2006">{{cite book|author=Margaret Scanlan|title=Culture and Customs of Ireland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bAKGzfpyWxMC&pg=PA84|date=1 January 2006|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-33162-6|pages=84}}</ref><ref name="Ferriter2010">{{cite book|author=Diarmaid Ferriter|title=Occasions of Sin: Sex and Society in Modern Ireland|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pUoWRaGQgRkC&pg=PA499|date=9 July 2010|publisher=Profile Books|isbn=1-84765-258-1|page=499}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/attitudes-may-have-changed-but-gaybashing-still-happens-29358960.html|title=Attitudes may have changed but gay-bashing still happens|first=John|last=Meagher|work=Irish Independent|date=21 June 2013}}</ref> * In January 1999, American expatriate writer Robert Drake was left permanently brain damaged after being assaulted by two men, Glen Mahon and Ian Monaghan, whom he had let into his home in [[Sligo]]. Drake was targeted because of his sexual orientation. The story of the attack and Drake's subsequent recovery became the subject of the 2013 documentary ''Where I Am''.<ref>http://www.phillymag.com/g-philly/2013/07/05/qfest-film-preview-making-where-am/</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/sligochampion/news/drake-to-return-to-sligo-to-make-documentary-27583506.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Drake to return to Sligo to make documentary | date=December 1, 2012}}</ref> * TV personality [[Mark O'Neill (TV personality)|Mark O'Neill]] and his partner came under a bloody attack from a [[gay bashing]] gang while walking on Patrick Street in Dublin in 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/around-town/rtes-mark-bloodied-in-gay-bash-gang-attack-2073850.html|title=RTÉ's Mark bloodied in 'gay bash' gang attack|date=22 February 2010|accessdate=22 February 2010|last=O'Keeffe|first=Alan|newspaper=Evening Herald}}</ref> * TV presenter [[Brendan Courtney]] was battered by a [[gay bashing]] stranger while walking home down South Great George's Street in Dublin in 2011. A man in his early twenties punched him in the face and shouted "[[queer]]" before running away. Courtney said it was "disgraceful" that such an incident could occur in Dublin.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/independent-woman/celebrity-news-gossip/tv-star-back-on-feet-after-attack-2538072.html|title=TV star back on feet after attack|date=13 February 2011|accessdate=13 February 2011|newspaper=Sunday Independent}}</ref> He told ''[[Liveline]]'' that more than 50 other gay people had told him of their own experiences of being assaulted or verbally abused in towns nationwide.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.herald.ie/entertainment/around-town/brendan-overwhelmed-by-support-after-attack-2540618.html|title=Brendan overwhelmed by support after attack|date=15 February 2011|accessdate=15 February 2011|author=Murphy, Claire|newspaper=Evening Herald}}</ref>
==Israel== * Three marchers in a [[Jerusalem gay pride parade|gay pride parade in Jerusalem]] on June 30, 2005 [[Jerusalem gay pride parade#2005 attack|were stabbed]] by [[Yishai Shlisel]], a [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi Jew]]. Shlisel claimed he had acted "in the name of God". He was charged with attempted murder.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4653655.stm|title=Man charged over Jerusalem attack|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=July 5, 2005|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting]] * On 30 July 2015, [[Jerusalem gay pride parade#2015 attack|five marchers were injured and one marcher was killed]], again by [[Yishai Shlisel]] when he stabbed them. It was three weeks after he was released from jail.
==Jamaica== * [[Brian Williamson]], Jamaican gay rights activist, was murdered on June 5, 2004 in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]]. His killer, Dwight Hayden, who used a [[machete]] to stab and chop him some 70 times, pleaded guilty<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20060504/news/news2.html|title=Man pleads guilty to murdering gay activist|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812003458/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20060504/news/news2.html|archivedate=2011-08-12|df=}}</ref> and received a life sentence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.asylumlaw.org/docs/sexualminorities/JamaicaUSCountRep030607.pdf|title=Country Reports on Human Rights Practices – 2006|publisher=Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor|date=March 6, 2007}}</ref> * An alleged gay man was chased down a [[pier]] by a Jamaican mob in December 2005. The man, fearful of the crowd, jumped into the water and drowned.<ref name="jamaica">{{cite news|url=http://www.gaywired.com/article.cfm?section=66&id=18055|title=Gay Men in Jamaica Attacked by Mob}}</ref> * An alleged gay student was attacked during a student riot in April 2006 at the [[University of the West Indies]] in Jamaica.<ref name="jamaica" /> * A group of gay men, including gay-rights activist Gareth Williams, were stoned by a mob in [[Mandeville, Jamaica]] on February 14, 2007. Their attackers reportedly had earlier demanded that the men leave the community.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://direland.typepad.com/direland/2007/02/jamaica_gay_lea.html|title=Jamaica: Gay Leader Escapes St. Valentine'S Day Lynch Mob|publisher=[[Direland]]}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/law/2005-6735.html|title=Homophobic mob attack Jamaican gay men|publisher=Pink News}}</ref> * During the funeral of a gay man in [[Mandeville, Jamaica]] on April 8, 2007, approximately 100 men gathered outside the church where 150 people were attending. According to mourners, the crowd broke the windows with bottles and shouted, "We want no battyman [gay] funeral here. Leave or else we’re going to kill you. We don’t want no battyman buried here in Mandeville." <ref name="jamaica"/> * Three gay men were attacked in the privacy of their dwelling in January, 2008 by an angry mob who had days before threatened them if they did not leave the community in Mandeville. According to reports, two men were hospitalised, one with serious injuries, while another man is still missing and feared dead.<ref name="jamaica" /><ref name="autogenerated1" />
==Martinique== *In 1964, American composer [[Marc Blitzstein]] was murdered in a homophobic attack by three sailors.<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Rest Is Noise |first=Alex |last=Ross |authorlink=Alex Ross (music critic) |page=383 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1-oK8NhvLNYC&pg=PA383 |publisher=Macmillan |year=2007}}</ref>
==Mexico== * May 22, 2016 reports indicate that at least five, and up to fifteen people are believed to have been killed in a mass shooting at La Madame. Three gunmen entered the Xalapa gay bar and carried out a mass shooting. Although the state prosecutor issued a statement noting that five people were killed, and were 14 injured, contradictory reports suggest there were many more deaths. Although police are searching for the gunmen, no arrests have been made.
==New Zealand== * [[Jeff Whittington]], a supposedly gay teenager, was beaten, kicked, and stomped to death by two men who reportedly later boasted of beating up a "[[faggot (slang)|faggot]]". The murder took place in [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]], on May 8, 1999. Whittington's attackers, Jason Morris Meads and Stephen James Smith, were sentenced to life in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/20087|title=Tax scam run from Rimutaka Prison}}</ref>
==Norway== * [[Magne Andreassen]] was murdered on August 21, 1992 in [[Lillehammer]]. The police investigation took about a year before [[Faust (musician)|Bård Faust]], the drummer of the band [[Emperor (band)|Emperor]], was tried and convicted of the killing. He was released from prison in 2002.<ref name="decibel">{{Cite news|url=http://decibelmagazine.com/Content.aspx?ncid=103042|title=Emperor – In the Nightside Eclipse|publisher=[[Decibel Magazine]]|accessdate=2009-01-14}}</ref><ref> {{Cite book|last=Kahn-Harris|first=Keith|title=Extreme metal: music and culture on the edge|volume=1|pages=45–46|publisher=Berg Publishers|publication-date=2007|isbn=1-84520-399-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9--qAVrfxukC|year=2007}}</ref>
==Portugal== * ''Gisberta Salce Júnior'', more commonly known in [[Portugal]] as the Gisberta case, was a homeless [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]] transsexual immigrant, who was [[HIV positive]], had drug problems, and was a sex-worker. She was found dead on 22 February 2006 inside a pit 10 metres deep, in an unfinished building in [[Porto]], the second biggest Portuguese city. The crime was confessed to by a group of 14 boys, between the ages of 10 and 16 years old, most of whom came from a child protection institution belonging to the Catholic Church, although financed by the state. From this confession, details of the dreadful act became known. The victim had a deeply fragile health condition, and these boys frequently harassed, insulted, and chased her. On the 19th, a group of these boys entered the unfinished and abandoned building where Gisberta was staying, tied her up, gagged and assaulted her with extreme violence, kicking her and beating her up with sticks and stones. The group also confessed to having introduced sticks into Gisberta's anus, whose body presented great injuries, and to having abandoned her at the scene. Her body also had cigarette-burn marks. On the 20th and 21st, they returned to the scene and repeated the aggressions. By dawn, from the 21st to 22nd, they finally threw her into the pit, attempting to hide the crime.<ref>[http://tgeu.org/gisberta-campaign-2006/ Gisberta Campaign (2006), Transgender Europe, 26.05.2017]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ilga.org/news_results.asp?LanguageID=1&FileCategory=6&FileID=823|title=Transexual Murdered in Portugal|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091030055245/http://www.ilga.org/news_results.asp?LanguageID=1&FileCategory=6&FileID=823|archivedate=2009-10-30|df=}}</ref>
==Serbia== * Participants of the first [[Gay pride parade#Belgrade|Serbian Pride Parade]] in [[Belgrade]] on June 30, 2001 were attacked by hundreds of Serbian [[nationalist]]s, [[skinhead]]s, and soccer hooligans.<ref name="Serbia">{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1415789.stm|title=In pictures: Belgrade gay march clashes|publisher=BBC News|date=June 30, 2001|accessdate=2009-01-15}}</ref>
==Sierra Leone== * [[FannyAnn Eddy]] was the most prominent [[Sierra Leone]]an gay and lesbian rights activist, working for Sierra Leone Lesbian and Gay Association (SLLGA) which she had founded in 2002, and had addressed the [[United Nations]] on lesbian and gay issues in her country during the discussion on the [[Brazilian Resolution]]. On September 28, 2004 Eddy was murdered while working alone in the [[Freetown]] SLLGA office. It is believed up to three men took part in the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/legacy/english/docs/2004/10/04/sierra9440_txt.htm|title=Sierra Leone: Lesbian Rights Activist Brutally Murdered}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/3716768.stm|title=Sierra Leone gay activist killed|publisher=BBC News | date=October 5, 2004}}</ref> Sierra Leone Police Force said that the murder could not be blamed on [[homophobia]], and dismissed the claim that she had been raped, or that there was more than one attacker. The one suspect that had been captured escaped from police custody before trial and has not been recaptured or prosecuted. Human rights activists are unclear whether this was a hate crime or not, but regard her attack by one or more individuals in the offices of SLLGA as significant. They have asked why only one suspected attacker was captured, expressed concern over repeated delays in prosecution, and how the suspect was able to escape custody.<ref name="EDDY">{{cite web|url=http://www.iglhrc.org/cgi-bin/iowa/article/takeaction/resourcecenter/374.html|title=Alleged Fannyann Eddy Murderer Reportedly Escapes Police Detention in Sierra Leone|publisher=IGLHRC|date=4 Oct 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iglhrc.org/cgi-bin/iowa/article/takeaction/resourcecenter/388.html|title=Sierra Leone: Clarification on the Murder of Fannyann Eddy|publisher=IGLHRC|date=Oct 4, 2004|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrol.com/articles/15308 |title=Sierra Leone lesbian activist murder "not a hate crime"|publisher=Afrol.com|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> In 2007 the [[Hirschfeld Eddy Foundation]] for the human rights of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people was established in [[Berlin]]; the name is a combination of Eddy and [[Magnus Hirschfeld]]'s names.
==South Africa== {{See also|Corrective rape|Lesbophobia}} * Two people were injured when Blah Bar, a gay bar in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]], was bombed in November 1999.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/507805.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Bomb blast in gay clubland|date=November 6, 1999|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Sizzlers massacre]] was a massacre that took place on January 20, 2003 at a gay massage parlour in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/horror-of-sizzlers-massacre-to-be-laid-bare-207259|title=Horror of Sizzlers massacre to be laid bare {{!}} IOL News|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en}}</ref> Nine men were brutally butchered to death and only one victim managed to escape. It was described by the High Court Judge and local police as one of the most vicious and bloodiest massacres the city of Cape Town had ever seen. * In [[Johannesburg]], [[Gauteng]], between 2011 and 2012 there were a number of serial killings that targeted 8 gay men who were murdered in their homes in strikingly similar circumstances. The men were all found with their hands tied behind their backs and there was no forced entry. The police made a statement saying It was believed that these men were targeted by a gang using online dating websites <nowiki/>in pretending to hook up with their victims and obtaining the trust of their victims who'd allow them into their homes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ewn.co.za/2013/04/18/Serial-killers-claim-9th-gay-victim|title=Serial killers claim 9th gay victim|last=News|first=Eyewitness|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en}}</ref> To this day, the case still remains a mystery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/gautengs-gay-serial-murder-mystery-1249585|title=Gauteng’s gay serial murder mystery {{!}} IOL News|access-date=2017-12-10|language=en}}</ref>
==Spain== * [[Julio Anderson Luciano]] and his [[fiancé]] [[Isaac Ali Dani Peréz Triviño]] were killed on January 13, 2006 in the home they shared with Peréz Triviño's mother in the Spanish city of [[Vigo]]. Jacobo Piñeiro Rial, who stabbed them 22 and 35 times, respectively, then set fire to the home, was sentenced to 20 years imprisonment for [[arson]] and later was [[acquitted]] by a regional jury of murder charges on a "[[gay panic]]" defense,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.typicallyspanish.com/news/publish/article_20321.shtml|title=Self confessed killer of two gay men gets 20 years for starting a fire|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301184522/http://www.typicallyspanish.com/news/publish/article_20321.shtml|archivedate=2012-03-01|df=}}</ref> and on July 12 of 2010, Piñeiro walked out of jail a free man. However, on September 26 a second jury found Piñeiro guilty of both murders as well as setting their place on fire and on October 14, 2010, he was sentenced to 58 years in jail, minus time already served (the maximum allowed time for this type of crime).
==St. Maarten== * Richard Jefferson, senior producer of ''[[CBS Evening News]]'', and Ryan Smith, producer-researcher of ''[[48 Hours (TV series)|48 Hours]]'', both [[United States|American]], were severely beaten with a [[tire iron]] on April 6, 2006 outside the Sunset Beach Bar on the [[Caribbean]] island of [[St. Maarten]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfbaytimes.com/index.php?sec=article&article_id=4911 |publisher=[[San Francisco Bay Times]] |title=CBS Producers Gay-Bashed On Vacation in Caribbean |accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref> Three men and one woman were convicted and sentenced to prison for the attack, which was ruled a hate crime.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iglhrc.org/cgi-bin/iowa/article/takeaction/resourcecenter/302.html |title=St. Maarten: Tribunal Decision On Attack Against Two Gay Tourists |publisher=IGLHRC|date=Nov 20, 2006 |accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref>
==Turkey== * Ahmet Yıldız, a gay man, was shot to death on July 15, 2008 in [[İstanbul]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ataman|first1=H.|last2=Cengiz|first2=O.K.|url=http://www.rightsagenda.org/attachments/523_T%C3%BCrkiyedeNefretSu%C3%A7lar%C4%B1.pdf|title=İnsan Hakları Gündemi Derneği|publisher=Türkiye'de nefret suçları|year=2009|accessdate=July 8, 2010|language=Turkish}}</ref>
==Uganda== * [[David Kato]], a prominent [[Uganda]]n gay rights activist, was beaten to death in his home on January 27, 2011. Mr. Kato had recently appeared on the front page of an anti-gay newspaper under the headline "Hang Them". Gay rights activists believe he was murdered for this reason, though the police say he was the victim of theft, not a hate crime.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/africa/28uganda.html?_r=1&hp|title=Ugandan Gay Rights Activist Is Beaten to Death|first=Jeffrey|last=Gettleman|publisher=The New York Times|date=January 27, 2011|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref>
==United Kingdom==
===England and Wales=== {{See also|History of violence against LGBT people in the United Kingdom}} * Kenneth Crowe, an English schoolteacher, aged 37, was found dead on 31 July 1950 in Rotherham, wearing his wife's clothes and a wig. He had approached a minor on his way home from the pub, who upon discovering Crowe was male, beat and strangled him.<ref name="MINER1">{{Cite news|title='Thought Man Was Woman' Story: Charge Is Now Murder|publisher=[[News of the World]]|date=5 Nov 1950}}</ref> John Cooney was found not guilty of murder and sentenced to five years for manslaughter.<ref name="MINER2">{{Cite news|title=He Killed Man Who Dressed As a Woman|publisher=News of the World|date=26 Nov 1950}}</ref> * [[George Brinham]], an English trade unionist, was killed in November 1962 in his flat by a young man, who claimed that Brinham had propositioned him. The killer was found not guilty of murder and manslaughter on the grounds of "provocation".<ref>"Youth cleared of Brinham manslaughter", ''[[The Guardian]]'', 22 January 1963</ref> * Christopher Schliach, a [[barrister]] who was gay, was murdered in his home in September 1989; he was stabbed more than 40 times.<ref name="LONUNS2" /> * Henry Bright, a [[hotel manager|hotelier]] who was gay, was stabbed to death at his home in December 1989.<ref name="LONUNS2" /> * William Dalziel, a hotel porter who was gay, was found unconscious on a roadside in Acton, west London in January 1990. He died from severe head injuries.<ref name="LONUNS2" /> * Michael Boothe, an actor who was gay, died in April 1990 in west London, beaten to death by a gang of up to six men close to a public lavatory.<ref name="LONUNS1" /> The police said he had been the victim of "an extraordinarily severe beating, of a merciless and savage nature". He managed to give a description of his attackers before he died, and a reward of [[£]]15,000 was offered, but no one was caught,<ref name="LONUNS2">{{Cite news|last=Richardson|first=Colin|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/aug/14/gayrights.comment|title=The worst of times|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 August 2002|location=London}}</ref> and the crime remains unsolved. The police review identified institutional homophobia within the [[Metropolitan Police]] as a factor.<ref name="LONUNS3">{{Cite news|last=Muir|first=Hugh|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2007/may/15/gayrights.ukcrime|title=Officers' homophobia hampered murder investigations, says review|publisher=The Guardian|date=15 May 2007|location=London}}</ref> * [[Colin Ireland]], age 43, was jailed for life in 1993 for murdering five gay men. Ireland picked up the men at pubs in London, and then killed them in their own homes.<ref name="LONUNS1">{{Cite news|first=Jason|last=Bennetto|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/gay-rights-a-matter-of-pride-for-the-metropolitan-police-552104.html|title=Gay Rights: A matter of pride for the Metropolitan Police?|publisher=Independent|date=5 July 2004|accessdate=9 April 2010|location=London}}</ref> A [[Scotland Yard]] review showed that Ireland's capture was hampered by institutional homophobia within the Metropolitan Police.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * Andrew Collier, a housing warden, aged 33, was one of Ireland's victims; the murder was classified as homophobic and linked with the death of Peter Walker, Ireland's first victim. The report said the police could have done more to warn the community of the links between the murders.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * Emanuel Spiteri, age 41, was strangled to death in his flat in Catford by Ireland, after meeting in a pub in Earls Court, west London.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * Robyn Brown, a 23-year-old trans sex worker, was found stabbed to death in her flat in London on 28 February 1997. The original report described her as being 23-year-old Gemma Browne, formerly James Darwin Browne.<ref name="GEMMA">{{Cite news|last=Graham|first=Polly|title=TV Nicky's DNA tested in hunt for tranny-killer; Watchdog start to help probe over stab death|publisher=[[Sunday Mirror]]|page=19|date=27 April 2003}}</ref> The case went cold for over ten years, but her killer, James Hopkins, was eventually caught; in January 2009 he was jailed for life.<ref name="YPROB">{{cite news|url=http://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/news/Transsexual-39was-killed-by-.4867222.jp|title=Transsexual 'was killed by a Jamaican'|publisher=[[Yorkshire Evening Post]]|date=13 January 2009}}</ref><ref name="METROB">{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/article.html?Killer_of_transexual_prostitute_jailed_for_life&in_article_id=498266&in_page_id=34|title=Killer of transexual prostitute jailed for life}}</ref> The report found that identifying her to the public using different names may have hampered attempts to connect with relevant communities.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> [[File:AdmiralDuncan.jpg|thumb|upright|London gay pub bombing in 1999 killed three and injured 70]] * In May 1999, the [[Admiral Duncan pub|Admiral Duncan]], a gay [[pub]] in [[Soho]] was bombed by former [[British National Party]] member [[David Copeland]], killing three people and wounding at least 70.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1999/05/99/the_nail_bomb_terror/333913.stm|title= Thousands remember Soho dead|publisher=BBC News|date= 2 May 1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgf.org.uk/news/1092/590/The-Admiral-Duncan-Bombing---10-years-on/|title=The Admiral Duncan Bombing – 10 years on|publisher=[[The Lesbian and Gay Foundation (UK)]]|date=30 April 2009}}</ref> * Jaap Bornkamp, a 52-year-old florist, was knifed in a homophobic attack in south-east London in June 2000; the murder remains unsolved despite the police displaying 20 ft by 10 ft images of [[CCTV]] footage taken near the murder scene. He was attacked after leaving a night club, and the police are reported as saying there was no confrontation or argument, but that the attack was homophobic and unprovoked.<ref name="LONUNS1" /> The report found this case to have been a model of police good practice.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * [[Damilola Taylor]] was attacked by a local gang of youths on 27 November 2000 in Peckham, south London; he bled to death after being stabbed with a broken bottle in the thigh, which severed the femoral artery. The BBC, Telegraph, Guardian and Independent newspapers reported at the time that during the weeks between arriving in the UK from [[Nigeria]] and the attack he had been subjected to bullying and beating, which included homophobic remarks by a group of boys at his school. "The bullies told him that he was gay."<ref name="BBCDAM">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1048449.stm|title=Damilola's grieving father speaks out|publisher=BBC News|date=30 Nov 2000}}</ref> He "may not have understood why he was being bullied at school, or why some other children taunted him about being 'gay' – the word meant nothing to him."<ref name="GUADAM" /> He had to ask his mother what 'gay' meant, she said "Boys were swearing at him, saying lots of horrible words. They were calling him names."<ref name="GUADAM">{{Cite news|last=Hopkins|first=Nick|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/nov/29/ukcrime.nickhopkins|title=Death of a schoolboy|newspaper=The Guardian|date=29 Nov 2000|location=London}}</ref> His mother had spoken about this bullying, but the teachers failed to take it seriously. "She said pupils had accused her son of being gay and had beaten him last Friday."<ref name="INDAM">{{Cite news|last=Bennetto|first=Jason|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/his-mother-told-teachers-he-was-being-bullied-now-she-must-bury-him-622144.html|title=His mother told teachers he was being bullied. Now she must bury him| newspaper=Independent|date=29 Nov 2000|location=London}}</ref> Six months after the murder, his father said, "I spoke to him and he was crying that he was being bullied and being called names. He was being called 'gay'."<ref name="TELDAM">{{Cite news|last=Steele|first=John|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1377304/Damilolas-father-attacks-loss-of-values.html|title=Damilola's father attacks loss of values|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=19 June 2001|location=London}}</ref> In the New Statesman two years later, when there had still been no convictions for the crime, Peter Tatchell, gay human rights campaigner, said, "In the days leading up to his murder in south London in November 2000, he was subjected to vicious homophobic abuse and assaults,"<ref name="NSDAM">{{Cite journal|last=Tatchell|first=Peter|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/200301130014|title=A victim of homophobia?|journal=New Statesman|date=13 Jan 2003}}</ref> and asked why the authorities had ignored this before and after his death. * Geoffrey Windsor, 57, in south London died in June 2002 from head injuries at Beaulieu Heights, a well-known gay cruising area, after he was beaten and robbed. The police said the murder was motivated by homophobia.<ref name="LONUNS1" /> A review of this and similar cases in the area highlighted poor policing due to institutional homophobia within the police, particularly in not taking previous attacks in the area more seriously.<ref name="LONUNS3" /> * [[Lauren Harries]], a trans woman and British media personality, was attacked in July 2005 along with her father and brother in their home in [[Cardiff]] by eight youths who shouted the word "tranny" while beating their victims. One youth pleaded guilty to inflicting grievous bodily harm and was sentenced to two years probation; his accomplices were not formally identified or charged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4216786.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Transsexual and family attacked|date=5 September 2005|accessdate=9 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/tm_objectid=16149951&method=full&siteid=50082&headline=youth-who-attacked-transsexual-spared-jail--name_page.html |title=Youth who attacked transsexual spared jail |publisher=WalesOnline |date=Sep 19, 2005 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217070221/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/tm_objectid%3D16149951%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D50082%26headline%3Dyouth-who-attacked-transsexual-spared-jail--name_page.html |archivedate=2009-02-17 |df= }}</ref> * [[Jody Dobrowski]] was beaten to death on 14 October 2005 on Clapham Common in London by two men who perceived him as being gay; Dobrowski was beaten so badly he had to be identified by his fingerprints. Thomas Pickford and Scott Walker were given life sentences in what was described as a 'homophobic murder' in June 2006.<ref name="DOB">{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/5087286.stm|title=Men jailed for gay barman murder|publisher=BBC News|date=16 June 2006}}</ref> This was the first prosecution in England and Wales where Section 146 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 was used in sentencing the killers; this enabled the courts to impose a tougher sentence for offenses motivated or aggravated by the victim's sexual orientation, in this case a minimum of 30 years in prison.<ref name="SOBCJA">{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article717120.ece|title=Two face 30 years in jail for homophobic murder|publisher=[[The Times]]|date=13 May 2006|location=London|first1=Roland|last1=Watson|first2=Miles|last2=Costello|first3=Sam|last3=Fleming}}</ref> * Rt Rev Dr Barry Rathbone, an openly gay priest, was attacked in April 2006. He was sitting in a park in Bournemouth, Dorset when Martin Powell and his girlfriend approached and spoke to him. Dr Rathbone informed them that it was a cruising area, then Powell produced a {{convert|3|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} metal baseball bat, called him a 'queer', and started to hit him, causing multiple injuries. Powell was subsequently jailed after plea bargaining down from attempted murder to assault occasioning serious bodily harm with intent and served 2 1/2 years in total. Dr Rathbone publicly forgave Powell in an interview with the BBC<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/dorset/4895796.stm|title=Man jailed for priest attack | work=BBC News | date=April 10, 2006}}</ref> * [[Michael Causer]], 18, was attacked by a group of men on 25 July 2008 at a party in [[Liverpool]], and died from his injuries. It is alleged that he was killed because he was gay.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/merseyside/7868151.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=Teenager 'killed for being gay'|date=3 February 2009|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * Daniel Jenkinson, 23, a gay [[hairdresser]], was the victim of a homophobic attack on 23 October 2008 in a [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]] club. His attacker, Neil Bibby, also from Preston, was sentenced to 200 hours' unpaid work, a three-month weekend [[curfew]], and ordered to pay £2,000 [[Damages|compensation]] after he pleaded guilty to [[assault]]. Daniel needed facial reconstruction surgery after the attack, and said he was too scared to go out in the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lep.co.uk/news/Gay-man-suffers-homophobic-attack.4824255.jp|title=Gay man suffers homophobic attack in club|publisher=lep.co.uk|date=Dec 26, 2008|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * Gerry Edwards, 59, and his partner of over twenty years, Chris Bevan, 56, were stabbed by an assailant shouting homophobic abuse on 3 March 2009 in [[London Borough of Bromley|Bromley]], south London. Gerry died from his injuries, and Chris was admitted to hospital in a critical condition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/4175826.BICKLEY__Police_name_59_year_old_murder_victim/|title=BICKLEY: Police name 59-year-old murder victim|publisher=Newsshopper.co.uk|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1159685/Man-stabbed-death-partner-seriously-wounded-homophobic-attack.html|title=Man stabbed to death and partner seriously wounded in 'homophobic attack'|publisher=[[The Daily Mail]]|date=6 March 2009|accessdate=2010-07-31|location=London}}</ref> The police dealing with the case said they had an open mind, but were treating it as a homophobic murder. Two men were subsequently arrested.<ref name="BROMLEY">{{Cite news|last=Taylor|first= Matthew|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/mar/06/fatal-stabbing-bromley-arrests|title= Two held over suspected homophobic murder|publisher=The Guardian|date=6 March 2009|location=London}}</ref> * [[Sol Campbell]], a [[association football|footballer]], was the target of disgruntled fans shouting homophobic abuse during a match. On 15 May 2009, an English court found two football fans guilty of shouting the homophobic chants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/UK-News/Sol-Campbell-Two-Guilty-Of-Chanting-Gay-Boy-At-Portsmouth-Footballer-At-Match-Against-Tottenham/Article/200905315282355?lpos=UK_News_News_Your_Way_Region_6&lid=NewsYourWay_ARTICLE_15282355_Sol_Campbell%3A_Two_Guilty_Of_Chanting_Gay_Boy_At_Portsmouth_Footballer_At_Match_Against_Tottenham|title=Pair Guilty Of Sol Campbell 'Gay Boy' Chants |publisher=sky.com|accessdate=2009-05-15}}</ref> This was the first prosecution for indecent chanting in the UK.<ref name = SOL/> The police reported that up to 2,500 fans shouted chants at the match that included "Sol, Sol, wherever you may be, Not long now until lunacy, We won't give a fuck if you are hanging from a tree," the footballer commented "I felt totally victimised and helpless by the abuse I received on this day. It has had an effect on me personally".<ref name="SOL">{{Cite news|title=Pair guilty of homophobic chants at footballer Sol Campbell|publisher=The Guardian|date=15 May 2009|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/may/15/sol-campbell-chant-guilty-portsmouth|location=London}}</ref> Three men and two boys were given cautions after the match.<ref name="SOL" />
===Scotland=== In 2009, the [[Scottish parliament]] unanimously passed legislation that means that crimes motivated by hatred of gay or disabled people will now be considered as 'aggravated offences'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8078988.stm|title=MSPs approve new hate crime laws|publisher=BBC News|date=3 June 2009}}</ref>
*6 April 1960. Queen's Park (near Hampdem Park), Glasgow. John Cremin murder. John Cremin was hit over the head with a flat piece of wood by 19-year-old [[Anthony Miller (murderer)|Antony Miller]] after being lured from a public toilet by a 16-year-old accomplice James Denovan. Cremlin fell to the ground with a fractured skull and died due to massive haemorrhaging. He was robbed of his bankbook, wallet, a knife and £67. This led to the last hanging in Scotland at Barlinnie Prison, convicted murderer Antony Millar 19 years old, on 22 December 1960 - the last teenager to be hanged in the 20th century before the death penalty ended. Anthony Millar was buried within Barlinnie as was common with hanged prisoners. Accomplice James Denovan at 16 was too young in law to face the death penalty.<ref name="Otton">{{cite book|title=Sexual Fascism|first=Garry|last=Otton|isbn=0-9541131-0-1}}</ref> *Summer 1995. Michael Doran, 35 years old, was violently attacked and murdered in Queen's Park Glasgow by a gang of three lads and a girl went on a queer bashing rampage. He received 83 blows to his body and was stabbed several times in the groin and stamped on, and broke every bone in his face. The gang then joined a nearby party and bragged about what they had done.<ref name="Otton" /> *April 2007. James Kerr Murder. A teenager who murdered a gay council worker in a public park in Perth was jailed for life. David Meehan, 19, from Perth, admitted murdering James Kerr in a homophobic attack at South Inch Park in April. Mr Kerr, 51, was left lying in a pool of blood with major head injuries while Meehan and his accomplices went to a party. David Meehan will serve at least 16 years in jail.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/tayside_and_central/7090628.stm|title=Homophobic killer jailed for life|publisher=BBC News|date=12 November 2007|accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref>
==United States== {{See also|History of violence against LGBT people in the United States}}
* Several men were assaulted on July 5, 1978, by a gang of youths armed with baseball bats and tree branches in an area of [[Central Park]] in New York City known to be frequented by homosexuals. The victims were assaulted at random, but the assailants later confessed that they had deliberately set out to the park to attack homosexuals. One of those injured was former figure skater [[Dick Button]], who was assaulted while watching a fireworks display in the park.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=July 7, 1978; July 8, 1978; July 9, 1978; July 13, 1978; July 14, 1978 |title=Dick Button}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.groups.yahoo.com/group/SkateFans/message/106545|title=Yahoo! Groups|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219231652/http://sports.groups.yahoo.com/group/SkateFans/message/106545|archivedate=2010-02-19|df=}}</ref> * [[Harvey Milk]], the openly gay [[San Francisco]] city supervisor, along with Mayor [[George Moscone]], were assassinated on November 27, 1978, by political rival [[Dan White]] at San Francisco City Hall.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Double Play: The Hidden Passions Behind the Double Assassination of [[George Moscone]] and [[Harvey Milk]]|first=Mike|last=Weiss|year=2010|isbn=978-0-9825650-5-6|publisher=Vince Emery Productions}}</ref> Outrage over the assassinations and the short sentence given to White (seven years) prompted the [[White Night Riots]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Mayor of Castro Street: The Life and Times of Harvey Milk|first=Randy|last=Shilts|year=1988|isbn=0-312-01900-9|publisher=MacMillan}}</ref> * In March, 1979, an assault on several women in a [[Peg's Place (bar)|San Francisco lesbian bar]] by off-duty police officers drew national attention to the strained relationship between police and [[LGBT culture in San Francisco|LGBT San Franciscans]] at that time. One woman was hospitalized for ten days with skull injuries.<ref>Josh Sides, Erotic City: Sexual Revolutions and the Making of Modern San Francisco, Oxford University Press, Oct 19, 2009, p.165</ref> * [[Tennessee Williams]] was the victim of an assault in January 1979 in [[Key West]], being beaten by five teenage boys. He escaped serious injury. The episode was part of a spate of anti-gay violence inspired by an anti-gay newspaper ad run by a local [[Baptist]] minister.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,912357,00.html|title=Key West: The Last Resort|publisher=[[Time Magazine]]|date=February 19, 1979}}</ref> * Steven Charles, 17, of [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] was beaten to death in [[New York City]] on October 7, 1979, by [[Costabile Farace|Costabile "Gus" Farace]], Robert DeLicio, David Spoto and Farace's cousin Mark Granato. They also beat Charles' friend, 16-year-old Thomas Moore of Brooklyn. Moore was critically injured but managed to get help at a nearby residence. It was Moore that identified the four men via a lineup four days after the incident. Farace, the leader of the attack, plead guilty to first-degree manslaughter. He was paroled after 8 years, in 1988. He himself was murdered on November 17, 1989.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Raab|first=Selwyn|title=Five Families: The Rise, Decline, and Resurgence of America's Most Powerful Mafia Empires|volume=1|publisher=St. Martin's Press|publication-date=2005|isbn=0-312-30094-8|year=2005}}</ref> * On November 18, 1980, Ronald K. Crumpley, a former Transit Authority policeman, fired 40 rounds from a semiautomatic rifle and two Magnum pistols (all stolen from a Virginia gun shop) into a cluster of men standing in front of two gay bars—Ramroad and the next-door Sneakers—in West Greenwich Village, killing 21-year-old Jörg Wenz, from the Netherlands, the Ramrod's doorman, and 32-year-old Vernon Kroening, from Minnesota, a church organist, and wounding six others. Rene Malute, 23, later died of his wounds. A survivor described the shootings as "a massacre, a bloodbath." Crumpley admitted to having paranoid delusions that gays were agents of the devil, stalking him and "trying to steal my soul just by looking at me." He was found not responsible by reason of insanity and committed to maximum-security Kirby Forensic Psychiatric Center on Ward's Island. In 2001, a judge denied Crumpley's request to be transferred to a less restrictive psychiatric facility. * [[Charlie Howard (murder victim)|Charlie Howard]] was drowned in [[Bangor, Maine]], in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.seacoastonline.com/news/06202006/maine/108334.htm|title=Portsmouth Herald Maine News: Victim thrown from bridge formerly lived in Portsmouth|publisher=Archive.seacoastonline.com|date=June 20, 2006|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * [[Rebecca Wight]] was killed on May 13, 1988, when she and her partner, [[Claudia Brenner]], were shot by Stephen Roy Carr while hiking and camping along the [[Appalachian Trail]]. Carr later claimed that he became enraged by the couple's lesbianism when he saw them having sex.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Brenna|first1= Claudia|last2=Ashley|first2= Hannah|title=Eight Bullets: One Woman's Story of Surviving Anti-Gay Violence|publisher=Firebrand Books|year=1995}}</ref> * [[James Zappalorti]] (1945–1990), a gay [[Vietnam War]] veteran, was stabbed to death.<ref name="nytimes">{{Cite news|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|title=S.I. Man, 44 Stabbed Dead On His Beach|first=James C.|last=McKinley, Jr.|date=January 25, 1990}}</ref> * [[Paul Broussard]] (1968–1991), a Houston-area banker, was murdered. * U.S. Navy Petty Officer [[Allen R. Schindler, Jr.|Allen Schindler]] was murdered by a shipmate who stomped him to death in a public restroom in Japan on October 27, 1992.<ref name="Jameson" /> Schindler had complained repeatedly about anti-gay harassment aboard ship.<ref name="Jameson">{{Cite news|last=Jameson|first=Sam|url=http://tech.mit.edu/V113/N28/sailor.28w.txt.html|accessdate=2008-03-21|title=U.S. Sailor Sentenced to Life Imprisonment in Murder|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=28 May 1993}}</ref> The case became synonymous with the [[gays]] in the military debate that had been brewing in the United States culminating in the "[[Don't ask, don't tell]]" bill.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mylifetime.com/on-tv/movies/any-mothers-son |title=Any Mother's Son – About the Movie |publisher=[[Lifetime Television]] |accessdate=2008-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080126022232/http://www.mylifetime.com/on-tv/movies/any-mothers-son |archivedate=2008-01-26 |df= }}</ref> * [[Brandon Teena]], a [[transman]], was raped and later murdered in 1993 when his birth gender was revealed by police to male friends of his.<ref name="bbio">{{Cite book|last=Jones|first=Aphrodite|title=All She Wanted|publisher=Pocket Books|year=1996}}</ref> The events leading to Teena's death were depicted in the movie ''[[Boys Don't Cry (film)|Boys Don't Cry]]''.<ref name="bfilm">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0171804/|title=Boys Don't Cry|publisher=[[IMDB]]}}</ref> * [[Scott Amedure]] was murdered on March 9, 1995, after revealing his attraction to his friend Jonathan Schmitz on a ''[[The Jenny Jones Show#The "Same Sex Crushes" controversy|The Jenny Jones Show]]'' episode about secret crushes. Schmitz purchased a shotgun to kill Amedure and did so after Amedure implied he still was attracted to him; Schmitz then turned himself in to police.<ref name="urlTalk-Show Guest Is Guilty Of Second-Degree Murder - New York Times">{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E5DE113BF930A25752C1A960958260 |title=Talk-Show Guest Is Guilty Of Second-Degree Murder – New York Times |last=Bradsher |first=Keith |date=Nov 13, 1996 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Z9xEOmO3?url=http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E5DE113BF930A25752C1A960958260 |archivedate=2008-07-08 |accessdate=2008-07-08 |publisher=The New York Times |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|last=Jennings|first=Marianne M.|title=Business: Its Legal, Ethical, and Global Environment|publisher=Thomson West|year=2005|page=388|isbn=0-324-20488-4}}</ref> * [[Roxanne Ellis and Michelle Abdill]], a [[lesbian]] couple in [[Medford, Oregon]], were murdered on December 4, 1995, by a man who said he had "no compassion" for bisexual or homosexual people.<ref>{{cite news|first=Charles|last=Burress|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1996/08/22/MN50950.DTL|title=Confessed Stockton Slayer Tells Motive / He changes story, implies he killed 2 women because they were lesbians|publisher=Sfgate.com|date=Aug 22, 1996|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Robert Acremant was convicted and [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]] by [[lethal injection]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.mailtribune.com/archive/2005/0318/local/stories/12local.htm|title=Death sentence upheld for lesbian couple's killer|publisher=Archive.mailtribune.com|date=March 18, 2005|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> * On December 5, 1997, [[Ali Forney]] was found by the police shot on the sidewalk in front of a housing project on East 131st Street. According to the ''[[New York Times]]'' he was the third young [[transgender]] [[prostitute]] murdered in [[Harlem]] in 14 months. The killing has never been solved.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/07/12/opinion/editorial-observer-helping-them-make-it-through-the-night.html?scp=1&sq=editorial%20Ali%20Forney&st=cse|title=Editorial Observer; Helping Them Make It Through the Night|publisher=The New York Times|date=July 12, 1998|accessdate=2016-07-09}}</ref> * The Otherside Lounge, a lesbian nightclub in [[Atlanta]], was bombed by [[Eric Robert Rudolph]], the "[[Centennial Olympic Park bombing|Olympic Park Bomber]]," on February 21, 1997; five bar patrons were injured. In a statement released after he was sentenced to five consecutive life terms for his several bombings, Rudolph called homosexuality an "aberrant lifestyle". * [[Matthew Shepard]] (1976–1998), a gay student, was fatally attacked in [[Laramie, Wyoming]] on October 7, 1998. Shepard was tortured, beaten severely, tied to a fence, and abandoned; he was found 18 hours after the attack and succumbed to his injuries less than a week later, on October 12. His attackers, Russell Arthur Henderson and Aaron James McKinney, are both serving two consecutive life sentences in prison.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Janofsky|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/11/05/us/parents-of-gay-obtain-mercy-for-his-killer.html|title=Parents of Gay Obtain Mercy For His Killer|publisher=The New York Times|date=November 5, 1999|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Gary Matson]] and [[Winfield Mowder]], a gay couple, were murdered on July 1, 1999, by [[white supremacist]] brothers Matthew and Tyler Williams in [[Redding, California]]. Tyler Williams was sentenced to a minimum of 33 years in prison, to be served after his completion of a 21-year sentence for firebombing synagogues and an abortion clinic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/niot/citizens_respond/redding.html|title=Not In Our Town - Citizens Respond to Hate - Redding|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> Benjamin Williams claimed that by killing the couple he was "obeying the laws of the Creator".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gaypeopleschronicle.com/stories/99nov12.htm|title=Lead News Stories from the Gay People's Chronicle|publisher=[[Gay People's Chronicle]]|accessdate=2010-07-31}}</ref> He committed suicide in 2003 while awaiting trial. Their former pastor described the brothers as "zealous in their faith" but "far from kooks".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/10/06/redding/print.html |title=Poster boys for the summer of hate |publisher=[[Salon.com|Salon]] |date=Oct 6, 1999 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926093339/http://www.salon.com/news/feature/1999/10/06/redding/print.html |archivedate=2011-09-26 |df= }}</ref> * U.S. Army Pfc. [[Barry Winchell]] was murdered on July 6, 1999, in [[Fort Campbell]], Kentucky by fellow soldier Calvin Glover. Winchell was beaten to death with a baseball bat after rumors spread on base of his relationship with transgender author [[Calpernia Addams]]. Glover was sentenced to life in prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=//www.davidclemens.com/gaymilitary/rolstobarry.htm |title=The Execution of Private Winchell |publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 2, 2000 |accessdate=2010-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060213230320/http://www.davidclemens.com/gaymilitary/rolstobarry.htm |archivedate=February 13, 2006 |df= }}</ref> * [[Steen Fenrich]] was murdered in September 1999, apparently by his stepfather, John D. Fenrich, in [[Queens]], New York. His dismembered remains were found in March 2001, with the phrase "gay nigger number one" scrawled on his skull along with his social security number. His stepfather fled from police while being interviewed, then committed suicide.<ref>{{cite news|first=David M.|last=Herszenhorn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/03/24/nyregion/signs-in-grisly-killing-point-to-bias-and-stepfather-who-killed-himself.html?sec=health&spon=&pagewanted=all|title=Signs in Grisly Killing Point to Bias and Stepfather Who Killed Himself|publisher=The New York Times|date=March 24, 2000|accessdate=April 9, 2010}}</ref> * [[Arthur Warren|Arthur "J.R."
